options.D: Exemption of GST on all such policies and their reinsurance
options.E: Introducing a special de-merit rate of 40% on high-value policies

questions.explanation: The press release on the 56th GST Council meeting explicitly states the council approved the 'Exemption of GST on all individual life insurance policies' and 'Exemption of GST on all individual health insurance policies' to make insurance more affordable.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
With reference to the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, which of the following provisions were among those that came into effect from 1st August 2025?
I. Redefining the threshold of ‘substantial interest’ from ₹5 lakh to ₹2 crore.
II. Permitting Public Sector Banks to transfer unclaimed shares and bond redemption amounts to the Investor Education and Protection Fund (IEPF).
III. Increasing the maximum tenure of cooperative bank directors (excluding the chairperson and whole-time director) from 8 years to 10 years.
questions.explanation: The press release on the Banking Laws (Amendment) Act, 2025, explicitly mentions that the provisions which came into force on 1st August 2025 include redefining 'substantial interest' to ₹2 crore, allowing PSBs to transfer unclaimed amounts to the IEPF, and increasing the tenure of cooperative bank directors to 10 years.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
Based on the Government's borrowing programme for H2 of FY 2025-26, which of the following statements about the maturity-wise distribution of borrowing is correct?
I. The highest share of borrowing, at 28.4%, is allocated to 10-year securities.
II. The combined share for 30-year and 50-year securities is 18.4%.
III. The share for 3-year securities (6.6%) is exactly half the share of 5-year securities (13.3%).

options.B: Only I and II are correct
options.C: Only II and III are correct
options.D: All I, II, and III are correct
options.E: Only I and III are correct

questions.explanation: Statement I is correct as 10-year securities have the largest share at 28.4%. Statement II is correct as the share for both 30-year and 50-year securities is 9.2%, summing up to 18.4%. Statement III is incorrect because 6.6% is not half of 13.3%. Therefore, only statements I and II are correct.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
Which of the following accurately reflects the key deliberations that emerged from the PSB Manthan 2025 event for Public Sector Banks (PSBs)?
I. A strong emphasis was placed on moving beyond legacy systems to agile, interoperable platforms and strengthening cyber resilience.
II. Collaboration with fintechs, academia, and global institutions was encouraged to enhance PSB capabilities and accelerate innovation.
III. It was suggested that PSBs should only focus on their traditional strengths in agriculture and MSMEs and avoid emerging sunrise sectors.
questions.explanation: The press release on PSB Manthan 2025 highlights the need for technology modernization (Statement I) and encourages collaboration with fintechs and academia (Statement II). Statement III is incorrect because the release explicitly states that while traditional strengths must be deepened, PSBs must also emerge as key enablers of sunrise sectors like renewable energy and semiconductors.
questions.source_type: PIB Press Release - Ministry of Finance
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Economic Survey 2023-24, what was the estimated real GDP growth rate for the financial year 2024 (FY24)?
questions.explanation: The preface of the Economic Survey 2023-24 states on page 8, 'In May, we learnt that the Indian economy is estimated to have grown 8.2% in real terms in FY24.'
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the Economic Survey 2023-24, the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) reached a 12-year low at the end of March 2024. What was this specific GNPA ratio?
questions.explanation: Page 93, paragraph 2.23 of the Economic Survey 2023-24 states, 'The gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio of SCBs continued its downward trend, reaching a 12-year low of 2.8 per cent at the end of March 2024 from its peak of 11.2 per cent in FY18.' This is also supported by Chart II.7a on page 94.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Economic Survey 2023-24 discusses the revamp of the Credit Guarantee Scheme (CGS) for Micro and Small Enterprises. What was the credit limit under this scheme enhanced to, from the previous limit of ₹2 crore?
questions.explanation: According to Box II.1 on page 92 of the Economic Survey 2023-24, under the revamp of the CGS for MSEs, 'the credit limit under the said scheme was enhanced from ₹2 crore to ₹ 5 crore, with a minimum annual guarantee fee of as low as 0.37 per cent per annum.'
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Preface of the Economic Survey 2023-24 describes the composition of private sector Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF) between FY19 and FY23 as 'not a healthy mix'. Which of the following best explains this assessment?

options.A: GFCF in machinery and equipment grew significantly faster than GFCF in dwellings and structures.
options.B: GFCF in dwellings and structures grew by 105%, significantly outpacing the 35% growth in machinery and equipment, indicating an imbalance.
options.C: Both machinery and dwellings GFCF components experienced a cumulative decline during the period.
options.D: The cumulative growth in general government GFCF was negative, while private sector GFCF remained stagnant.
options.E: The growth in intellectual property products was the sole driver of private sector GFCF, while other components lagged.

questions.explanation: The Preface of the Economic Survey 2023-24 (page 10) states that private sector GFCF in 'machinery and equipment and intellectual property products' grew by only 35% in the four years to FY23, while its GFCF in 'Dwellings, other buildings and structures' increased by 105%. The document explicitly calls this trend 'not a healthy mix,' highlighting the concern that investment in less productive assets (structures) is growing much faster than in more productive ones (machinery).
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Economic Survey 2023-24 projected a real GDP growth range for FY25, while the Economic Survey 2024-25 provided the First Advance Estimate for the same year. What is the difference in percentage points between the lower bound of the initial projection and the First Advance Estimate?
questions.explanation: The Economic Survey 2023-24 (page 82) projected a real GDP growth of '6.5–7 per cent' for FY25, making the lower bound 6.5%. The Economic Survey 2024-25 (page 46, paragraph 1.22) states that the First Advance Estimate for FY25 real GDP growth is '6.4 per cent'. The difference is the later estimate minus the earlier projection's lower bound: 6.4% - 6.5% = -0.1 percentage points.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's estimated real GDP growth rate in FY24?
questions.explanation: According to the Economic Survey, India's real GDP grew by 8.2 per cent in FY24, marking the third consecutive year of growth over 7 per cent. This information is stated in the Preface and Chapter 1. (page 8, 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the fiscal deficit of the Union Government as a percentage of GDP in FY24, according to provisional actuals?
questions.explanation: The fiscal deficit of the Union Government was brought down from 6.4 per cent of GDP in FY23 to 5.6 per cent of GDP in FY24, as per provisional actuals data. (page 64)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) reached a 12-year low in March 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: Data from the RBI's Financial Stability Report shows that the asset quality of SCBs improved, with the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio declining to a 12-year low of 2.8 per cent in March 2024. (page 74, 93)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total number of Initial Public Offers (IPOs) in FY24, marking a 66 per cent increase from FY23?
questions.explanation: The number of initial public offers (IPOs) increased by 66 per cent in FY24 from 164 in FY23 to 272 in FY24, reflecting robust primary market activity. (page 110)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which scheme was launched in September 2023 to provide recognition, skill upgradation, and credit support to traditional artisans and craftspeople across 18 trades?
questions.explanation: The PM Vishwakarma programme was launched in September 2023 to provide end-to-end support for traditional artisans and craftspeople working with traditional tools across 18 trades. (page 314)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average retail inflation rate (CPI inflation) in India during FY24?
questions.explanation: Domestic inflationary pressures moderated in FY24. After averaging 6.7 per cent in FY23, retail inflation declined to 5.4 per cent in FY24. (page 26, 132)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's Current Account Deficit (CAD) as a percentage of GDP for the fiscal year FY24?
questions.explanation: The Current Account Deficit (CAD) narrowed significantly to 0.7 per cent of GDP in FY24, an improvement from the 2.0 per cent deficit in FY23, supported by a lower trade deficit and robust services exports. (page 8, 28, 75)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The manufacturing sector's Gross Value Added (GVA) showed a strong recovery in FY24. What was the growth rate of manufacturing GVA in FY24?
questions.explanation: Within the industrial sector, manufacturing GVA grew by 9.9 per cent in FY24, benefiting from reduced input prices and stable domestic demand. (page 57)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Household Consumption Expenditure Survey (HCES) 2022-23, by what percentage did the Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) in rural areas increase in real terms over 2011-12?
questions.explanation: The HCES 2022-23 results showed that the Monthly Per Capita Consumption Expenditure (MPCE) in rural areas increased in real terms by 40 per cent over 2011-12. (page 220)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The PM-KISAN scheme is a central sector scheme to supplement the financial needs of land-holding farmers. What is the annual economic benefit transferred to each eligible farmer's family under this scheme?
questions.explanation: Under the PM-KISAN scheme, an economic benefit of ₹6,000 per year is transferred in three equal four-monthly instalments into the bank accounts of farmers’ families. (page 331)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The female labour force participation rate (FLFPR) has shown a consistent rise over the past six years. What was the FLFPR in 2022-23 according to the annual PLFS?
questions.explanation: The female labour force participation rate has been rising for six years, increasing from 23.3 per cent in 2017-18 to 37 per cent in 2022-23, mainly driven by the rising participation of rural women. (page 79, 277)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Bank credit growth sustained momentum during FY24. What was the YoY growth in credit disbursal by Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) at the end of March 2024?
questions.explanation: Credit disbursal by SCBs stood at ₹164.3 lakh crore, growing by 20.2 per cent at the end of March 2024, compared to a 15 per cent growth at the end of March 2023. (page 91)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As part of India's climate action commitments, what was the share of non-fossil fuel-based energy sources in the total installed electricity generation capacity as of May 2024?
questions.explanation: The composition of the electricity sector has changed significantly, with the share of non-fossil power capacity being 45.4 per cent as of May 2024, up from around 32 per cent in April 2014. (page 187, 230)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Union Budget for FY23 announced a revamp of the Credit Guarantee Scheme (CGS) for Micro and Small Enterprises (MSEs). What was the amount infused into the corpus of the Credit Guarantee Fund Trust for MSEs?
questions.explanation: To facilitate an additional credit of ₹2 lakh crore for MSEs, the CGS was revamped with an infusion of ₹9,000 crore in the corpus of Credit Guarantee Fund Trust for MSEs. (page 92)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Net Interest Margin (NIM) of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The Net Interest Margin (NIM) of SCBs remained robust at 3.6 per cent in March 2024, having moderated from its peak of 3.9 per cent in Q1 of FY24. (page 94-95)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Amid a healthy economic performance, what was the total value of capital formation facilitated by primary markets in FY24?
questions.explanation: Primary markets remained robust during FY24, facilitating capital formation of ₹10.9 lakh crore, compared to ₹9.3 lakh crore in FY23. (page 110)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the total outlay of the PM Formalization of Micro Food Processing Enterprises (PMFME) scheme, which provides credit-linked subsidy and capacity building?
questions.explanation: The PMFME scheme was launched with a total outlay of ₹10 Thousand Crore to provide credit-linked subsidy, capacity building, marketing, and branding support to micro food processing enterprises. (page 342)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Yearly net payroll additions to the EPFO more than doubled between FY19 and FY24. What were the approximate figures for net payroll additions in these two years?

options.A: From 50 lakh in FY19 to 110 lakh in FY24
options.B: From 61.1 lakh in FY19 to 131.5 lakh in FY24
options.C: From 78.6 lakh in FY19 to 150 lakh in FY24
options.D: From 65 lakh in FY19 to 140 lakh in FY24
options.E: From 55.5 lakh in FY19 to 125.5 lakh in FY24

questions.explanation: The yearly net payroll additions to the EPFO more than doubled from 61.1 lakh in FY19 to 131.5 lakh in FY24, showing a swift recovery from the pandemic. (page 282)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The compounded quarterly growth rate (CQGR) of India's deseasonalised quarterly GDP was higher in the post-pandemic period (Q3FY21 - Q4FY24) compared to the pre-pandemic period (Q1FY12 - Q4FY20). What were these respective growth rates?
questions.explanation: Analysis reveals that the compounded quarterly growth rate (CQGR) of deseasonalised quarterly GDP was greater in the period Q3 FY21 – Q4 FY24 at 1.9% than the CQGR of 1.5% in the pre-pandemic period of Q1 FY12 – Q4 FY20. (Table I.1, page 63)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Between FY19 and FY23, private sector Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF) showed varied growth across its components. What was the cumulative growth in GFCF for 'Dwellings, other buildings and structures' compared to 'machinery and equipment and intellectual property products'?
questions.explanation: A breakdown of private sector GFCF shows a significant divergence. Between FY19 and FY23, GFCF in 'Dwellings, other buildings and structures' increased by 105%, while GFCF in 'machinery and equipment and intellectual property products' grew cumulatively by only 35%. (page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The National Monetisation Pipeline (NMP) has a potential of ₹6 lakh crore over FY22-FY25. What were the total monetisation receipts recorded from FY22 to FY24 against the target of ₹4.3 lakh crore for that period?
questions.explanation: The National Monetisation Pipeline (NMP) listed assets with a potential of ₹6 lakh crore for monetisation over FY22–FY25. During the period FY22-FY24, receipts worth ₹3.9 lakh crore have been recorded against a target of ₹4.3 lakh crore. (page 66)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The composition of merchandise exports shifted in FY24, with the share of capital goods rising substantially. What was the share of capital goods in merchandise exports in FY24 compared to FY23?

options.A: From 15.1% in FY23 to 17.5% in FY24
options.B: From 16.3% in FY23 to 18.9% in FY24
options.C: From 17.0% in FY23 to 19.5% in FY24
options.D: From 14.8% in FY23 to 18.2% in FY24
options.E: From 16.9% in FY23 to 19.1% in FY24

questions.explanation: There was a notable shift in the composition of exports. The share of capital goods in merchandise exports rose substantially from 16.3 per cent in FY23 to 18.9 per cent in FY24, indicating improved supplies of machinery and equipment. (page 111)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The total number of subscribers under the National Pension Scheme (NPS) and Atal Pension Yojana (APY) registered a YoY growth of 18 per cent as of March 2024. The total number of subscribers increased from what level in March 2023 to what level in March 2024?
questions.explanation: India's pension sector expanded significantly, with the total number of subscribers under NPS and APY standing at 735.6 lakh as of March 2024, registering a YoY growth of 18 per cent from 623.6 lakh as of March 2023. (page 125)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the revamped Credit Guarantee Scheme (CGS) for MSEs, guarantees worth ₹2.02 lakh crore were extended in FY24. Of this amount, what were the respective guarantee amounts extended to women-owned and SC/ST-owned enterprises?

options.A: ₹25,123 crore to women & ₹4,393 crore to SC/ST
options.B: ₹30,523 crore to women & ₹5,093 crore to SC/ST
options.C: ₹32,223 crore to women & ₹5,393 crore to SC/ST
options.D: ₹35,823 crore to women & ₹6,193 crore to SC/ST
options.E: ₹28,423 crore to women & ₹4,893 crore to SC/ST

questions.explanation: Under the revamped CGS for MSEs, guarantees worth ₹2.02 lakh crore were extended in FY24, out of which ₹32,223 crore were extended to women-owned enterprises and ₹5,393 crore were extended to SC/ST-owned enterprises. (page 92)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the analysis of India's post-pandemic recovery using deseasonalised macroeconomic variables, which major variable was identified as still lagging behind its pre-pandemic trend projection as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The visualisation of key macroeconomic variables reveals that while GDP, GVA, private consumption, GFCF, and industrial GVA have recovered quickly to their pre-pandemic trends, the GVA of the services sector is yet to reach the level projected by its pre-pandemic trend. (Chart I.32, page 62)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the first advance estimates, what is India's real GDP growth estimated to be for FY25?
questions.explanation: As per the first advance estimates released by the National Statistical Office (MoSPI), the real gross domestic product (GDP) growth for FY25 is estimated to be 6.4 per cent. (Page 56, Para 1.22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected range for India's real GDP growth in FY26?
questions.explanation: On balance of considerations regarding robust domestic fundamentals and global headwinds, the survey expects that the growth in FY26 would be between 6.3 and 6.8 per cent. (Page 78, Para 1.73)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the PM - Surya Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana, what is the target for residential rooftop solar capacity to be installed in one crore households?
questions.explanation: The PM - Surya Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana aims to install rooftop solar plants in one crore households, which is expected to enable approximately 30 gigawatts of residential rooftop solar capacity. (Page 289, Para 10.35)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above in 2023-24, as per the annual Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) report?
questions.explanation: As per the 2023-24 annual PLFS report, the unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above has steadily declined from 6 per cent in 2017-18 to 3.2 per cent in 2023-24. (Page 76, Para 1.65)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the RBI kept the policy repo rate unchanged during the first nine months of FY25. What was this rate?
questions.explanation: During the first nine months of FY25 (April 2024-December 2024), the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the RBI decided to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent. (Page 81, Para 2.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the Amrit Bharat Station Scheme, how many railway stations have been identified for redevelopment to enhance passenger amenities?
questions.explanation: Under the Amrit Bharat Station Scheme, which is aimed at enhancing railway station amenities, 1337 stations have been identified for redevelopment, with work having started in 1197 of them. (Page 212, Box VI.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks declined to a 12-year low at the end of September 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: The GNPA ratio of SCBs has declined consistently to a 12-year low of 2.6 per cent at the end of September 2024. (Page 84, Para 2.9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's Current Account Deficit (CAD) as a percentage of GDP in Q2 of FY25?
questions.explanation: India's current account deficit (CAD) moderated slightly to 1.2 per cent of GDP in Q2 of FY25, against 1.3 per cent of the GDP recorded in Q2 of FY24. (Page 149, Para 3.44)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The first advanced estimates of agricultural production for 2024-25 project a record total Kharif food grain production. What is the estimated figure?
questions.explanation: As per the first advanced estimates of agricultural production for 2024-25, total Kharif food grain production is estimated at a record 1647.05 lakh metric tonnes (LMT). (Page 59, Para 1.29)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the growth rate of Private Final Consumption Expenditure (PFCE) in H1 FY25?
questions.explanation: Private Final Consumption Expenditure (PFCE) firmed up in H1 FY25, growing by 6.7 per cent YoY, with indicators suggesting that rural demand contributed to this growth. (Page 62, Para 1.36)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the RBI's OBICUS survey, what was the seasonally adjusted capacity utilisation (CU) in manufacturing firms in Q2 FY25?
questions.explanation: The RBI’s Order Books, Inventory, and Capacity Utilisation Survey (OBICUS) showed that the seasonally adjusted capacity utilisation (CU) in manufacturing firms was 74.7 per cent in Q2 FY25, which is above the long-term average of 73.8 per cent. (Page 64, Para 1.40)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Retail headline inflation (CPI) softened during April – December 2024 compared to FY24. What was the average CPI inflation during this period?
questions.explanation: Retail headline inflation, as measured by the CPI, softened from 5.4 per cent in FY24 to 4.9 per cent in April – December 2024. (Page 70, Para 1.52)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of December 31, 2024, how many Ayushman Arogya Mandirs (AAMs) have been operationalised under the Ayushman Bharat initiative?
questions.explanation: Under Ayushman Bharat, 1,75,560+ Ayushman Arogya Mandirs (formerly Health & Wellness Centres) have been operationalised as of 31 December 2024. (Page 377, Table XI.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the targeted production capacity of Green Hydrogen per annum under the National Green Hydrogen Mission?
questions.explanation: The National Green Hydrogen Mission aims to achieve a production capacity of about five million metric tonnes per annum of Green Hydrogen. (Page 290, Para 10.42)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The textile and apparel industry contributes approximately what percentage to India's GDP?
questions.explanation: The textile and apparel industry contributes 2.3 per cent of GDP, 13 per cent to industrial production, and 12 per cent to exports. (Page 139, Para 3.26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the 2024 Global Innovation Index, what was India's rank among 133 economies?
questions.explanation: India’s rank in the Global Innovation Index has improved to 39th in 2024 among 133 economies from its 81st position in 2015. (Page 249, Box VII.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Female Labour Force Participation Rate (FLFPR) in India in 2023-24, primarily driven by the rising participation of rural women?
questions.explanation: The female labour force participation rate (FLFPR) has been rising for seven years, from 23.3 per cent in 2017-18 to 41.7 per cent in 2023-24. (Page 415, Para 12.16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks as of September 2024?
questions.explanation: At the end of September 2024, the Capital to Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks stood at 16.7 per cent, well above the regulatory norm. (Page 84, Para 2.10 & Chart II.3b)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following service sub-sectors, being contact-intensive, had not yet surpassed its pre-pandemic trend level by the first half of FY25?

options.A: Financial, real estate and professional services
options.B: Public administration, defence, and other services
options.C: Trade, hotels, transport, and communication services

questions.explanation: The recovery within the services sector has been uneven. While financial services and public administration surpassed pre-pandemic trend levels, 'trade, hotels, transport, and communication services' are still gradually catching up with the pre-pandemic trend. (Page 57, Para 1.27 & Chart I.26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Arrange the following sectors in descending order of their share in total FDI equity inflows during H1 of FY25: 1. Computer software and hardware 2. Services Sector 3. Trading 4. Non-conventional energy
questions.explanation: In H1 of FY25, the Services sector was the largest recipient of FDI (19.1%), followed by computer software and hardware (14.1%), trading (9.1%), and non-conventional energy (7.0%). (Page 152, Para 3.51 & Chart III.15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the analysis of the PDS/PMGKAY subsidy in 2022-23, what was the approximate value of the subsidy as a percentage of household consumption for the rural bottom 20 per cent?
questions.explanation: The imputation exercise suggests that in 2022-23, the value of the PDS/PMGKAY subsidy accounted, on average, for seven per cent of household consumption among the rural bottom 20 per cent, compared to only two per cent among the top 20 per cent. (Page 351, Box XI.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Considering the data on vocational training for the 15-59 age group in 2023-24, which statement is correct regarding the sources of training?

options.A: Formal vocational training is the largest source of skilling.
options.B: Self-learning accounts for a larger share of the workforce than learning on the job.
options.C: The majority of the workforce, over 65%, received no vocational training.
options.D: Hereditary training is more common than learning on the job.
options.E: More than 25% of the workforce has received some form of vocational training.

questions.explanation: The PLFS 2023-24 data shows that 65.3% of the workforce in the 15-59 age group received no form of vocational training. Hereditary training (11.6%) was the most common source, followed by Learning on the Job (9.3%) and Self Learning (7.1%). (Page 399, Chart XII.22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the NITI Aayog working paper's strategic classification of service sub-sectors, which of the following falls under the 'Sectors to accelerate' category, characterized by low-moderate export and moderate-high GVA & employment share?
questions.explanation: The NITI Aayog framework classifies sectors with low-moderate export and moderate-high GVA & employment share under 'Sectors to accelerate'. This category includes trade & repair, transport, education, and financial services. (Page 270, Chart VIII.9 Summary)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Between FY14 and FY24, what was the approximate increase in the share of consumer credit in total bank credit?
questions.explanation: Between FY14 and FY24, the share of consumer credit in total bank credit increased significantly from 18.3 per cent to 32.4 per cent, indicating a major shift in the financial sector. (Page 122, Para 2.89)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the performance of India's construction and manufacturing sub-sectors in the post-pandemic recovery up to H1 FY25?

options.A: Both manufacturing and construction GVA have surpassed their pre-pandemic trends significantly.
options.B: Manufacturing GVA is well above its pre-pandemic trend, while construction GVA is lagging behind.
options.C: Construction GVA is approximately 15% above its pre-pandemic trend, whereas manufacturing is still slightly below its trend.
options.D: Both sectors are recovering but remain significantly below their respective pre-pandemic trend levels.
options.E: Manufacturing and construction have recovered at an identical pace, both hovering just at their pre-pandemic trend lines.

questions.explanation: A closer look at industrial sub-sectors shows that construction has been a standout, soaring approximately 15 per cent above its pre-pandemic trend. In contrast, manufacturing, while steadily recovering, remains slightly below its pre-pandemic trajectory. (Page 57, Para 1.26 & Chart I.25)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged throughout 2023-24. What was this rate?
questions.explanation: Considering the growth-inflation dynamics, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.50 per cent during 2023-24. (Page 29, para I.14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the Indian economy for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Taking into account various domestic economic factors, the real GDP growth for 2024-25 is projected at 7.0 per cent with risks evenly balanced. (Page 34, para I.38)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected CPI inflation for the financial year 2024-25, with risks considered evenly balanced?
questions.explanation: Taking into account factors like supply chain pressures, core inflation, and monsoon outlook, the CPI inflation for 2024-25 is projected at 4.5 per cent with risks evenly balanced. (Page 35, para I.40)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Effective October 1, 2024, the Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework for NBFCs was extended to include government NBFCs, with an exception for which category?

options.C: Those with asset size below ₹500 crore

questions.explanation: The Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework has been extended to government NBFCs (except those in Base Layer) and it would be applicable with effect from October 1, 2024. (Page 31, para I.24; Page 160, para VI.78)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total value of ₹2000 denomination banknotes in circulation as on May 19, 2023, when their withdrawal was announced?
questions.explanation: The total value of ₹2000 banknotes in circulation was ₹3.56 lakh crore as on May 19, 2023. (Page 69, footnote 36)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In 2023-24, what was the average spread of the weighted average call rate (WACR) relative to the policy repo rate?

options.A: 13 basis points below the repo rate
options.B: 13 basis points above the repo rate
options.D: 12 basis points below the repo rate
options.E: 12 basis points above the repo rate

questions.explanation: The weighted average call rate (WACR) traded, on an average, 13 basis points (bps) above the policy repo rate during 2023-24, compared to 12 bps below the rate in 2022-23. (Page 29, para I.14; Page 78, para II.5.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the guidelines on Default Loss Guarantee (DLG) in digital lending, the DLG is limited to what percentage of the outstanding loan portfolio?
questions.explanation: The guidelines on DLG in digital lending lay down several regulatory guardrails, including limiting the DLG to five per cent of the outstanding loan portfolio. (Page 143, para VI.21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As a temporary measure to absorb surplus liquidity from the return of ₹2000 banknotes, an incremental cash reserve ratio (I-CRR) of 10 per cent was imposed during which period in 2023?
questions.explanation: An incremental cash reserve ratio (I-CRR) of 10 per cent was applied as a temporary measure from the fortnight beginning August 12, 2023 to October 7, 2023 to absorb surplus liquidity. (Page 106, para III.2; Page 111, para III.16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What percentage of the ₹2000 banknotes in circulation on May 19, 2023, had been returned to the banking system by March 31, 2024?
questions.explanation: Of the ₹3.56 lakh crore of ₹2000 banknotes in circulation as on May 19, 2023, when the withdrawal was announced, 97.7 per cent had returned to the banking system up to March 31, 2024. (Page 181, para VIII.14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total surplus amount transferred by the Reserve Bank to the Central Government for the financial year 2023-24?
questions.explanation: For the year 2023-24, the surplus transferred to the Central Government amounted to ₹2,10,873.99 crore, a significant increase from ₹87,416.22 crore in the previous year. (Page 243, Table XII.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the share of ₹500 denomination banknotes in the total value of banknotes in circulation as on March 31, 2024?
questions.explanation: As of end-March 2024, the ₹500 denomination banknotes constituted 86.5 per cent of the total value of banknotes in circulation, increasing from 77.1 per cent in the previous year. (Page 180, Table VIII.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During 2023-24, liquidity conditions tightened, causing the average daily net absorption under the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) to moderate significantly. What was the average daily net absorption figure for 2023-24?
questions.explanation: Liquidity conditions tightened during 2023-24. The average daily net absorption under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) moderated to ₹485 crore during 2023-24 from ₹1.87 lakh crore in the previous year. (Page 29, para I.14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI revised the definition of 'Bulk Deposits' for Regional Rural Banks (RRBs) in October 2023. What is the new threshold for a single Rupee term deposit to be classified as a 'Bulk Deposit' for RRBs?
questions.explanation: On October 26, 2023, the Reserve Bank enhanced the bulk deposit limit for RRBs. 'Bulk Deposit' for RRBs would now mean single Rupee term deposits of ₹ one crore and above, revised from the earlier limit of '₹15 lakh and above'. (Page 146, para VI.33; Annex I, page 279)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As on March 22, 2024, what was the money multiplier (MM)?
questions.explanation: As on March 22, 2024, the money multiplier (MM) was 5.4, which was marginally higher than its decennial average of 5.3 (2013-14 to 2023-24). (Page 72, para II.4.11; Page 73, Table II.4.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During the monetary tightening cycle from May 2022 to March 2024, by how many basis points did the weighted average domestic term deposit rate (WADTDR) on outstanding term deposits increase?
questions.explanation: In the tightening cycle from May 2022 to March 2024, the WADTDR on outstanding term deposits increased by 185 basis points. During the same period, the policy repo rate was increased by 250 bps. (Page 115, Table III.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI announced regulatory measures on investments in Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs) on December 19, 2023, with clarifications issued on March 27, 2024. Which of the following clarifications is correct?

options.A: Downstream investments by AIFs include both equity shares and other instruments.
options.B: Provisioning by a Regulated Entity (RE) applies to the entire investment in the AIF scheme, not just the proportionate part.
options.C: Proposed deductions from capital due to AIF investments affect only Tier-1 capital.
options.D: Investments in AIFs through intermediaries such as fund of funds are beyond the scope of the circular.
options.E: REs are mandated to liquidate investments only if the AIF's downstream investment is in the form of debt.

questions.explanation: The clarification issued on March 27, 2024, advised that: (i) downstream investments exclude equity shares; (ii) provisioning applies on a proportionate basis; (iv) deductions affect both Tier-1 and Tier-2 capital; and (v) investments in AIFs through intermediaries like fund of funds are beyond the scope of the circular. (Page 144, para VI.26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The revised prudential norms for the investment portfolio of commercial banks, issued on September 12, 2023, introduced several key modifications. Which of the following was NOT one of these modifications?

options.A: Principle-based classification of investment portfolio into HTM, AFS, and FVTPL categories.
options.B: Removal of the 90-day ceiling on the holding period for the 'Held for Trading' (HFT) category.
options.C: Removal of the ceiling on investments in the 'Held to Maturity' (HTM) category.
options.D: Mandatory inclusion of all Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR) securities in the HTM category.
options.E: Symmetric recognition of gains/losses for investments under AFS and FVTPL categories.

questions.explanation: The revised Directions included the inclusion of non-statutory liquidity ratio (SLR) securities in the HTM category, subject to fulfilling certain conditions. It did not mandate the inclusion of all SLR securities. Other mentioned modifications are correct as per the report. (Page 145, para VI.27)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the percentage increase in the size of the Reserve Bank's balance sheet for the year ended March 31, 2024?
questions.explanation: The size of the balance sheet increased by ₹7,02,946.97 crore, which is an 11.08 per cent increase, from ₹63,44,756.24 crore as on March 31, 2023 to ₹70,47,703.21 crore as on March 31, 2024. (Page 243, para XII.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the primary reason for the decrease in the Reserve Bank's holdings of domestic securities (Investments-Domestic-BD) from ₹14,06,422.89 crore in 2023 to ₹13,63,368.97 crore in 2024?

options.A: A strategic shift towards increasing foreign investments.
options.B: Transfer of securities to the Central Government to manage fiscal deficit.
options.C: Liquidity management operations involving net sale and redemption of government securities.
options.D: Directives from the Monetary Policy Committee to reduce domestic asset holdings.
options.E: Revaluation losses due to an increase in domestic bond yields.

questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank’s holding of domestic securities decreased mainly on account of liquidity management operations conducted by way of net sale of government securities and redemption of securities in the portfolio. (Page 262, para V)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The new standardised approach for operational risk capital requirements for banks is based on a combination of a Business Indicator Component (BIC) and an Internal Loss Multiplier (ILM). Which of these components is applicable only to larger banks?

options.C: Both BIC and ILM are for larger banks only
options.D: Neither, both are applicable to all banks
options.E: A modified version of BIC is used for smaller banks

questions.explanation: Under the new standardised approach for operational risk, banks are required to consider a financial statement-based business indicator component (BIC), along with a loss data-based internal loss multiplier (ILM) [for larger banks] in their capital calculation. This implies ILM is specifically for larger banks. (Page 145, para VI.28)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its February 2025 meeting, what was the policy repo rate set by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)?
questions.explanation: The MPC unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent in its February 2025 meeting. This was the first rate reduction since February 2023. (Page 89, 112, 115)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: To ease potential liquidity stress, the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) was reduced by 50 bps in December 2024. What is the new CRR as a percentage of NDTL?
questions.explanation: The CRR of banks was reduced by 50 bps in two equal tranches of 25 bps each, bringing it down to 4.0 per cent of Net Demand and Time Liabilities (NDTL) effective from the fortnight beginning December 28, 2024. (Page 86, 112, 285)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the value of the RBI's Financial Inclusion Index (FI-Index) for the period ending March 2024?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank’s Financial Inclusion Index (FI-Index) improved from 60.1 in March 2023 to 64.2 in March 2024, indicating deepening of financial inclusion in the country. (Page 35, 130)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI issued a revised Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework for Urban Co-operative Banks (UCBs). From which date will this framework become effective?
questions.explanation: The revised Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework for UCBs, issued on July 26, 2024, will be effective from April 1, 2025. It is applicable to all UCBs in Tier 2, Tier 3, and Tier 4 categories. (Page 139, 288)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average spread of the Weighted Average Call Rate (WACR) over the policy repo rate during the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: During 2024-25, the Weighted Average Call Rate (WACR), on an average, remained 6 basis points above the policy repo rate, compared to 13 bps in the previous year. (Page 95, 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In which month of 2024 did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decide to change its policy stance from 'withdrawal of accommodation' to 'neutral'?
questions.explanation: Buoyed by a well-balanced inflation-growth dynamics, the MPC unanimously decided in its October 2024 meeting to change the policy stance from withdrawal of accommodation to neutral to provide it the flexibility to monitor the progress of ongoing disinflation. (Page 114)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the revised guidelines for the voluntary transition of Small Finance Banks (SFBs) to Universal Banks, what is the minimum net worth requirement for an eligible SFB?
questions.explanation: According to the eligibility criteria issued on April 26, 2024, Small Finance Banks (SFBs) are required to have a minimum net worth of ₹1,000 crore as at the end of the previous quarter to be eligible for transition into a universal bank. (Page 127)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: By the end of March 2025, the Central Bank Digital Currency-Retail (e₹-R) pilot had been expanded to how many banks and users respectively?
questions.explanation: As at end-March 2025, the pilot program for the e₹-R segment was expanded to include 17 banks and 60 lakh users since its inception in December 2022. (Page 34)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In February 2025, the RBI reviewed the risk weights on SCBs' exposure to NBFCs. What was the outcome of this review?

options.A: Increased the risk weights by a further 25 percentage points.
options.B: Restored the risk weights to the level associated with the external rating of the NBFC.
options.C: Introduced a uniform risk weight of 125% for all NBFC exposures.
options.D: Kept the increased risk weights from November 2023 unchanged.
options.E: Reduced the risk weights by 50 percentage points from the November 2023 levels.

questions.explanation: Following a review, a circular dated February 25, 2025, restored the risk weight on SCBs' funding to NBFCs back to the risk weight associated with the given external rating of the NBFCs, reversing the earlier increase for cases where the rating was below 100 per cent. (Page 127, 286)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average daily net absorption under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) during 2024-25, indicating that liquidity conditions remained in surplus for the year as a whole?
questions.explanation: For the year as a whole, liquidity conditions remained in surplus, reflected in an average daily net absorption under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) which increased to ₹1,605 crore during 2024-25 from ₹485 crore in the previous year. (Page 31)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI launched 'FinTech Repository' and 'EmTech Repository' on May 28, 2024. Which entity is responsible for managing these secure web-based applications?

options.A: Department of Payment and Settlement Systems (DPSS)
options.D: Institute for Development and Research in Banking Technology (IDRBT)

questions.explanation: The 'FinTech Repository' and 'EmTech Repository' were launched to capture information about FinTech entities and the adoption of emerging technologies by regulated entities. These secure web-based applications are managed by the Reserve Bank Innovation Hub (RBIH). (Page 34, 159)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a move to enhance credit availability for small and marginal farmers, the limit for collateral-free agricultural loans was raised in December 2024. What is the revised limit per borrower?
questions.explanation: Keeping in view the rise in agricultural input costs and overall inflation, the limit for collateral-free agriculture loans was raised from ₹1.6 lakh to ₹2 lakh per borrower in December 2024, effective January 1, 2025. (Page 129, 278)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In June 2024, the RBI revised the definition of 'bulk deposits' for scheduled commercial banks (excluding RRBs) and small finance banks. What is the new threshold for a single rupee term deposit to be classified as a bulk deposit?
questions.explanation: On a review, the definition of bulk deposits was revised to ‘Single Rupee Term Deposits of ₹3 Crore and Above’ for SCBs (excluding RRBs) and SFBs, up from the previous limit of ₹2 crore. (Page 283)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the voting pattern of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) for the decision to reduce the policy repo rate in the February 2025 meeting?
questions.explanation: In the February 2025 meeting, the MPC unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 bps to 6.25 per cent, marking a shift towards a growth-supportive stance. (Page 115)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the analysis of liquidity drivers in FY 2024-25, which of the following was the largest single factor contributing to the withdrawal of liquidity from the banking system?

options.A: Build-up of Government of India Cash Balances
options.C: Build-up of Excess Reserves by banks
options.D: Net Forex Sales by the RBI

questions.explanation: As per Table III.1 on 'Liquidity – Key Drivers and Management', Net Forex Sales led to a liquidity withdrawal of ₹2,91,233 crore in FY 2024-25, which was larger than the withdrawal due to Currency in Circulation (₹2,04,703 crore). (Page 117)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which statement accurately reflects the monetary policy transmission to bank lending and deposit rates during 2024-25, despite a 25 bps repo rate cut in the final quarter?

options.A: WALR on fresh loans increased by 2 bps, while WADTDR on fresh deposits increased by 3 bps.
options.B: WALR on fresh loans declined by 2 bps, while WADTDR on fresh deposits increased by 3 bps.
options.C: Both WALR on fresh loans and WADTDR on fresh deposits declined by more than 10 bps.
options.D: Both WALR on fresh loans and WADTDR on fresh deposits increased marginally.
options.E: WALR on fresh loans declined by 8 bps, while WADTDR on fresh deposits declined by 14 bps.

questions.explanation: During 2024-25, the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans declined by 2 bps. In contrast, the Weighted Average Domestic Term Deposit Rates (WADTDRs) on fresh deposits increased by 3 bps, showing a divergent trend in transmission. (Page 96, Table III.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The transmission of monetary policy to outstanding rupee loans was observed to be lower for Public Sector Banks (PSBs) compared to Private Sector Banks (PVBs). What is the primary reason for this difference?

options.A: PSBs have a larger share of corporate loans which are less sensitive to repo rate changes.
options.B: PSBs have a significantly lower share of EBLR-linked loans and a higher share of loans linked to legacy benchmarks like MCLR and Base Rate.
options.C: PVBs were quicker to reduce their Marginal Cost of Funds-based Lending Rate (MCLR).
options.D: PSBs' deposit costs did not decrease, preventing them from lowering lending rates.
options.E: Regulatory forbearance allowed PSBs to delay the transmission of policy rate changes.

questions.explanation: The transmission to WALR on outstanding rupee loans was lower for PSBs due to a comparatively higher share of internal benchmark-based lending rates, viz., MCLR and others. The share of EBLR-linked loans for PVBs (85.9%) was significantly higher than for PSBs (44.6%) as of December 2024. (Page 98)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following a comprehensive internal review of the Economic Capital Framework (ECF), what is the revised range for the Contingent Risk Buffer (CRB) as a percentage of the RBI's balance sheet?
questions.explanation: The reviewed ECF widened the range for monetary and financial stability buffers. Consequently, the Contingent Risk Buffer (CRB) would be maintained in the range of 6.0 ± 1.5 per cent of the Balance Sheet size, as against the previous level of 6.5 per cent with a lower bound of 5.5 per cent. (Page 209)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following correctly matches the RBI's recent regulatory/supervisory initiative with its primary objective?

options.A: PRAVAAH: To manage liquidity through open market operations.
options.B: sDQI (Supervisory Data Quality Index): To assess and improve the quality of risk data reporting by supervised entities.
options.C: RB-CRIS (Climate Risk Information System): To provide a platform for reporting of financial frauds.
options.D: SAKAR Framework: To facilitate the transition of Small Finance Banks to Universal Banks.
options.E: FinTech Repository: To manage the RBI's internal employee data and HR functions.

questions.explanation: The Supervisory Data Quality Index (sDQI) was developed to identify and address deficiencies in risk data aggregation capabilities and risk reporting practices across Supervised Entities (SEs). The other options are mismatched: PRAVAAH is for regulatory applications, RB-CRIS is for climate risk data, SAKAR is for KYC/AML risk assessment, and FinTech Repository is for capturing information on FinTech entities. (Page 34, 40, 126, 141, 146)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the surplus amount transferred by the Reserve Bank to the Central Government for the year 2024-25, and what was its approximate year-on-year growth?
questions.explanation: The surplus payable to the Central Government for FY 2024-25 was ₹2,68,590.07 crore. This represented an increase of 27.37 per cent over the ₹2,10,873.99 crore transferred in the previous year. (Page 223, 249)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation recorded in February 2025, which marked a seven-month low?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article highlights that India’s macroeconomic strength is bolstered by a decline in headline CPI inflation to a seven-month low of 3.6 per cent in February 2025. (Page 31)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the approximate percentage of maintainable complaints under the RBI’s Integrated Ombudsman Scheme in 2023-24 that required mediation or formal intervention from the RBI Ombudsmen?
questions.explanation: In the speech titled 'Transforming Grievance Redress: The AI Advantage', it is mentioned that nearly 57 per cent of the maintainable complaints in 2023-24 required mediation or formal intervention by the RBI Ombudsmen. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to a World Bank report cited in the bulletin, what was the estimated value of personal remittances received by India in 2024, making it the largest recipient globally?
questions.explanation: In the speech on Digital Payments Awareness Week 2025, it is stated that as per a World Bank report, it has been estimated that in 2024, India received remittances totalling approximately 130 billion USD. (Page 18-19)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the 2023-24 survey data on inward remittances by banks, which of the following groups of Advanced Economies (AEs) collectively surpassed a 50% share of India's total remittances, reflecting a shift from GCC countries?

options.A: United States, United Kingdom, and Canada
options.B: United States, United Arab Emirates, and Singapore
options.C: United States, United Kingdom, Singapore, Canada, and Australia
options.D: United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and Germany
options.E: United States, Singapore, Australia, and New Zealand

questions.explanation: The article 'Changing Dynamics of India’s Remittances' notes that the US, UK, Singapore, Canada, and Australia together accounted for more than half of remittances in 2023-24. A calculation from Table 1 confirms this: US (27.7%) + UK (10.8%) + Singapore (6.6%) + Canada (3.8%) + Australia (2.3%) equals 51.2%. (Page 99)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation rate recorded in June 2025, marking the fifth consecutive month it remained below 4 per cent?
questions.explanation: According to the 'State of the Economy' article, headline inflation, as measured by y-o-y changes in the CPI, declined to 2.1 per cent in June 2025, which was the lowest since January 2019. (Page 44)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of June 2025, what percentage of India's installed power capacity was accounted for by non-fossil fuel sources, achieving a major energy transition target five years ahead of schedule?
questions.explanation: The document states that as of June 2025, non-fossil fuel sources accounted for 50.1 per cent of India’s installed power capacity. This achieved the Nationally Determined Contributions target of around 50 per cent by 2030, five years ahead of schedule. (Page 43, Chart III.9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the value of the composite Financial Inclusion (FI)-Index in 2024, as mentioned in the bulletin?
questions.explanation: The bulletin notes that the composite Financial Inclusion (FI)-Index, which measures the extent of financial inclusion, improved substantially from 49.9 in 2019 to 64.2 in 2024. (Page 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on an empirical analysis presented in the bulletin, what is the estimated impact on India's headline inflation for every 10 per cent increase in international crude oil prices?

options.A: An increase of around 10 basis points
options.B: An increase of around 15 basis points
options.C: An increase of around 20 basis points
options.D: An increase of around 25 basis points
options.E: An increase of around 30 basis points

questions.explanation: The article 'Revisiting the Oil Price and Inflation Nexus in India' concludes that a 10 per cent increase in international crude oil prices could raise India's headline inflation by around 20 basis points on a contemporaneous basis. (Page 66, 74)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the sectoral deployment of bank credit data for May 2025, which of the following sectors experienced a year-on-year contraction in credit from scheduled commercial banks?
questions.explanation: Chart A6: 'Sectoral Deployment of Bank Credit' shows that for May 2025, the year-on-year growth for 'Services Credit - NBFC' was -0.3%, indicating a contraction. This is also supported by the text which states, 'Bank credit to NBFCs, on a y-o-y basis, contracted in May 2025'. (Page 51, Page 63)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of early September 2024, what was the all-time high level reached by India's foreign exchange reserves?
questions.explanation: According to the 'State of the Economy' article, as of September 6, 2024, India’s foreign exchange reserves rose to an all-time high of US$ 689.2 billion. This was equivalent to more than 12 months of imports for 2023-24. (Page 113)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of banks reached its lowest level since end-March 2011 at the end of June 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: In the speech on 'Global Financial Stability', it is mentioned in a footnote that the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of banks was 2.7 per cent at end-June 2024, which was the lowest since end-March 2011. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In September 2024, the union cabinet approved the 'PM E-DRIVE' scheme to promote the electric vehicle ecosystem. What is the financial outlay for this scheme?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article mentions that the union cabinet approved the Electric Drive Revolution in Innovative Vehicle Enhancement (PM E-DRIVE) scheme on September 11, 2024 with an outlay of ₹10,900 crore. (Page 82)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the first quarter of 2024-25, what was the growth rate registered by the manufacturing sector, as measured by Gross Value Added (GVA)?
questions.explanation: As per the 'State of the Economy' article, within the industrial sector, the manufacturing component recorded a strong growth of 7.0 per cent in Q1:2024-25. Overall GVA expanded by 6.8 per cent. (Page 90)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: With reference to the financial stability indicators for banks and Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) as of end-June 2024, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.A: The Gross NPA ratio for banks stood at 2.7 per cent, its lowest since March 2011.
options.B: The Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for NBFCs was significantly above the regulatory threshold, standing at 26.6 per cent.
options.C: The annualized Return on Assets (RoA) for banks at 1.4 per cent was higher than the RoA for NBFCs.
options.D: The annualized slippage ratio for banks, measuring new NPA accretions, continued to decline and reached 1.3 per cent.
options.E: The Gross NPA ratio of NBFCs was 2.8 per cent, its lowest level since March 2021.

questions.explanation: Statement C is incorrect. According to the data provided, the annualized Return on Assets (RoA) for banks stood at 1.4 per cent, while the RoA for NBFCs stood at 3.2 per cent at end-June 2024. Therefore, the RoA for NBFCs was higher than that for banks. All other statements are correct based on the information in the footnote. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Approximately how many transactions per month were processed through the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) as of May 2025?
questions.explanation: The document highlights the success of India's digital transformation, noting that the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) was processing about 18 billion transactions in a month. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) at the end of December 2024?
questions.explanation: According to the document, the soundness of scheduled commercial banks was bolstered by adequate capital buffers, with their capital to risk-weighted assets (CRAR) standing at 16.5 per cent at the end of December 2024. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the central government’s budgeted fiscal deficit as a percentage of GDP for the fiscal year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: The bulletin states that the government is committed to fiscal consolidation, with the central government's fiscal deficit to GDP ratio budgeted to moderate further to 4.4 per cent in 2025-26. (Page 9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the approximate value of India's mobile phone exports in the fiscal year 2023-24, reflecting the success of policies like the Production-Linked Incentive (PLI) scheme?
questions.explanation: The document highlights that policy measures like the PLI are showing results, with mobile phone exports increasing from 1.6 billion USD in 2018-19 to 15.6 billion USD in 2023-24. (Page 10, Footnote 9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Union Budget 2025 proposed raising the Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) limit in the insurance sector to 100 per cent, subject to what specific condition?

options.A: At least 50% of the board members must be Indian citizens.
options.B: The foreign entity must form a joint venture with a public sector insurer.
options.C: The company must be listed on an Indian stock exchange within five years.
options.D: The entire premium collected must be invested within India.
options.E: A minimum of 30% of its workforce must be employed from rural areas.

questions.explanation: Footnote 1 on page 7 clarifies the details of the FDI liberalisation in the insurance sector. It specifies that the announced increase in the FDI cap to 100 per cent comes 'with the condition that the entire premium is invested within India.' This requires careful reading of the details provided in the footnote. (Page 7, Footnote 1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the Monetary Policy Committee meeting in April 2025, what was the new policy repo rate set at?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points to 6.00 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the financial year 2025-26 as per the April 2025 Monetary Policy Statement?
questions.explanation: Taking all factors into consideration, the real GDP growth for 2025-26 is projected at 6.5 per cent, with quarterly breakdowns of Q1 at 6.5%, Q2 at 6.7%, Q3 at 6.6%, and Q4 at 6.3%. (Page 9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the April 2025 Statement on Developmental and Regulatory Policies, which entity has been proposed to be empowered to revise transaction limits for Person to Merchant (P2M) UPI payments based on evolving user needs?

options.E: Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI)

questions.explanation: It is proposed that NPCI, in consultation with banks and other stakeholders of the UPI ecosystem, may announce and revise transaction limits for P2M payments based on evolving user needs, while the P2P transaction cap remains at ₹1 lakh. (Pages 19, 20)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the level of India's foreign exchange reserves as of April 4, 2025?
questions.explanation: As of April 4, 2025, India’s foreign exchange reserves stood at 676.3 billion US dollars, which provided an import cover of about 11 months. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial soundness parameters for December 2024, which of the following statements correctly compares the performance of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) and Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs)?

options.A: The Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for SCBs was higher than that for NBFCs.
options.B: The Return on Assets (RoA) for SCBs was higher than that for NBFCs.
options.C: NBFCs had a lower Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio than SCBs.
options.D: NBFCs had a higher Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio than SCBs.
options.E: Both SCBs and NBFCs reported a Return on Assets (RoA) below 1%.

questions.explanation: As per the data in the footnotes, in December 2024, the GNPA ratio for NBFCs was 2.53%, while for SCBs it was 2.42%. Therefore, the GNPA ratio of NBFCs was higher than that of SCBs. The CRAR for NBFCs (26.22%) was higher than SCBs (16.43%), and the RoA for NBFCs (2.86%) was higher than SCBs (1.37%). (Page 11, footnotes 23 & 26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its October 2024 meeting, what policy repo rate did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decide to maintain?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee, in its meeting from October 7-9, 2024, decided by a majority of 5 out of 6 members to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.50 per cent. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for India for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Taking various domestic and global factors into consideration, the real GDP growth for 2024-25 is projected at 7.2 per cent. (Page 9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the October 2024 Monetary Policy Statement, what is the projected CPI inflation for the financial year 2024-25?

questions.question: Following the recent policy announcements to enhance digital payments, what is the new per-transaction limit for UPI Lite?
questions.explanation: To encourage wider adoption of UPI, it has been decided to increase the UPI Lite wallet limit to ₹5,000 and the per-transaction limit from ₹500 to ₹1,000. (Pages 14, 22)

questions.question: Under the risk scenarios analyzed for the baseline inflation path, what is the estimated increase in domestic inflation if international crude oil prices rise by 10 per cent above the baseline assumption?
questions.explanation: The risk analysis section of the Monetary Policy Report indicates that if crude oil prices were to be 10 per cent above the baseline, domestic inflation could be higher by around 30 basis points (bps). (Page 34)

questions.question: In its meeting from June 4-6, 2025, what was the policy repo rate decided by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to reduce the policy repo rate under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) by 50 basis points to 5.50 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the level of India’s foreign exchange reserves as on May 30, 2025?
questions.explanation: The document states that as on May 30, 2025, India’s foreign exchange reserves stood at US$ 691.5 billion, sufficient to fund more than 11 months of goods imports. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the financial year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: Taking all factors into consideration, the real GDP growth for 2025-26 is projected at 6.5 per cent, with quarterly projections of Q1 at 6.5%, Q2 at 6.7%, Q3 at 6.6% and Q4 at 6.3%. (Page 9, 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Reserve Bank announced a phased reduction in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) during 2025. What will be the new CRR as a percentage of Net Demand and Time Liabilities (NDTL) after the reduction is fully implemented?
questions.explanation: It has been decided to reduce the cash reserve ratio (CRR) by 100 basis points (bps) to 3.0 per cent of net demand and time liabilities (NDTL) in a staggered manner, with the full reduction effective by November 29, 2025. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial parameters of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) for December 2024, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

options.A: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio improved to 2.42 per cent from 2.96 per cent a year ago.
options.B: The Net Interest Margin (NIM) showed a year-on-year expansion.
options.C: The system-level Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) was 16.43 per cent.
options.D: The annualised Return on Assets (RoA) stood at 1.37 per cent.
options.E: The Net Non-Performing Assets (NNPA) ratio improved to 0.55 per cent from 0.69 per cent in December 2023.

questions.explanation: According to footnote 40, the Net Interest Margin (NIM) was 3.49 per cent for December 2024, which is a contraction compared to 3.64 per cent in December 2023. Therefore, the statement that NIM showed a year-on-year expansion is incorrect. All other statements are factually correct based on the data provided in the footnote. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the Monetary Policy Committee meeting in February 2025, what was the new policy repo rate set at?
questions.explanation: In its February 2025 meeting, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points, bringing it down from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's Current Account Deficit (CAD) as a percentage of GDP in the second quarter of the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: India’s current account deficit (CAD) moderated to 1.2 per cent of GDP in Q2:2024-25, down from 1.3 per cent of GDP in the corresponding quarter of the previous year. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: To enhance trust and combat digital fraud in the financial sector, the Reserve Bank of India announced the implementation of an exclusive internet domain for Indian banks. What is this new domain?
questions.explanation: As a measure to enhance digital security, the Reserve Bank announced it shall implement the ‘bank.in’ exclusive Internet Domain for Indian banks to help avoid banking frauds like phishing. This will be followed by a 'fin.in' domain for the wider financial sector. (Page 11, 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the targeted Gross Fiscal Deficit (GFD) as a percentage of GDP for the fiscal year 2025-26, as per the Union Budget assessment?
questions.explanation: The Union Budget 2025-26 balances growth imperatives with fiscal prudence by targeting a Gross Fiscal Deficit (GFD) at 4.4 per cent of GDP for the Budget Estimates (BE) of 2025-26, down from the Revised Estimates (RE) of 4.8 per cent in 2024-25. (Page 77)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During the monetary policy tightening period from May 2022 to December 2024, the repo rate increased by 250 basis points. In this context, which statement accurately compares the monetary policy transmission to fresh deposits and fresh rupee loans between Public Sector Banks (PSBs) and Private Sector Banks (PVBs)?

options.A: Transmission to fresh deposit rates was higher in PVBs, while transmission to fresh lending rates was higher in PSBs.
options.B: PSBs demonstrated higher transmission than PVBs in both fresh deposit rates and fresh lending rates.
options.C: PVBs showed stronger transmission than PSBs across both fresh deposit and fresh lending rates.
options.D: Transmission to fresh lending rates was higher in PVBs, while transmission to fresh deposit rates was higher in PSBs.
options.E: Both bank groups experienced identical transmission in fresh deposit rates, but PSBs had a lower transmission in fresh lending rates.

questions.explanation: During the May 2022 to December 2024 period, Public Sector Banks (PSBs) showed a higher transmission of the policy rate hike. The Weighted Average Domestic Term Deposit Rate (WADTDR) on fresh deposits increased by 274 bps for PSBs compared to 214 bps for Private Sector Banks (PVBs). Similarly, the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans increased by 177 bps for PSBs versus 163 bps for PVBs. (Page 62, Charts IV.11 and IV.12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What real GDP growth has the Reserve Bank of India projected for the fiscal year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: In a speech on the Indian macroeconomic experience, it was stated that for the current year (2024-25), the Reserve Bank of India has projected real GDP growth of 7.2 per cent, with risks evenly balanced around this forecast. (Page 20)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its meeting in October 2024, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) changed its policy stance to 'neutral'. What was the immediate prior stance?
questions.explanation: In the meeting on October 7-9, 2024, the MPC decided to change the monetary policy stance from 'withdrawal of accommodation' to 'neutral' to provide greater flexibility in responding to evolving economic conditions. (Page 13)

questions.question: According to the data on India's external sector, what was the Current Account Deficit (CAD) as a percentage of GDP for the fiscal year 2023-24?
questions.explanation: The bulletin states that India's current account deficit (CAD) remained within a manageable limit, standing at 0.7 per cent of GDP in FY 2023-24. This compares to 1.1 per cent in Q1:2024-25 and 2.0 per cent in FY 2022-23. (Page 14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Indian banks as a percentage of total assets at the end of June 2024?
questions.explanation: As part of improving financial soundness, impairment in banks' balance sheets was brought down, with Gross non-performing assets reaching just 2.7 per cent of total assets at the end of June 2024. (Page 27)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
Considering India's recent export performance, which of the following statements is/are correct?
1. India holds approximately one-sixth of the global market share in petroleum products.
2. India ranks as the world's largest exporter of insecticides.
3. In the global semiconductor export market, India is ranked ninth.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is correct as the document states, 'India currently holds 13 per cent or a sixth of the global market share in petroleum products'. Statement 2 is incorrect; India is the 'third largest exporter of insecticides', not the largest. Statement 3 is correct as India is ranked 'ninth in semiconductors'. Therefore, only statements 1 and 3 are correct. (Page 39)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's total renewable energy capacity, including wind, solar, hybrid, biomass, small hydro, and nuclear, as of December 2024?
questions.explanation: According to the 'State of the Economy' article, the total renewable energy capacity in India – comprising wind, solar, hybrid, biomass, small hydro, and nuclear – stood at 209.4 GW as of December 2024. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the first advance estimates by the National Statistics Office (NSO), what was the projected real GDP growth for India for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The first advance estimates (FAE) of national income, released on January 7, 2025, placed the real GDP growth for 2024-25 at 6.4 per cent. This was a moderation from the 8.2 per cent growth recorded a year ago. (Page 9, 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the first advance estimates for 2024-25, what was the positive contribution of net exports to India's GDP growth?
questions.explanation: In 2024-25, India’s exports grew by 5.9 per cent while imports contracted by 1.3 per cent. This enabled net exports to contribute positively to GDP growth by 1.7 percentage points. (Page 16)

questions.question: The share of gold in the Net Foreign Assets (NFA) of the Reserve Bank saw a significant increase, rising from 8.1 per cent at the end of October 2023 to what level as on January 10, 2025?
questions.explanation: On the sources side (assets), the share of gold in NFA increased from 8.1 per cent as at end-October 2023 to 11.2 per cent as on January 10, 2025, mainly due to revaluation gains. (Page 37)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the context of India's aggregate supply for 2024-25, which of the following statements correctly reflects the growth performance of the key GVA sectors?

options.A: The agriculture sector, with a growth of 5.2%, outperformed the services sector which grew at 3.8%.
options.B: The industrial sector's GVA growth was the highest at 8.6%, driven by strong manufacturing performance.
options.C: The services sector demonstrated resilience with a growth of 7.4%, while the industrial sector's GVA growth subsided to 5.2%.
options.D: Both industrial GVA and services sector GVA grew at an identical rate of 6.4%.
options.E: Manufacturing slackened to 7.4%, while growth in the construction sub-sector moderated to 5.3%.

questions.explanation: For 2024-25, the services sector growth remained resilient at 7.4 per cent. In contrast, industrial GVA growth subsided to 5.2 per cent, with manufacturing slackening to 5.3 per cent. Agriculture growth was 3.8 per cent. This makes statement C the only correct representation of the sectoral performance. (Page 25, 26)
