questions.question: In the Monetary Policy Committee meeting of August 2025, what was the policy repo rate maintained at?

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the financial year 2025-26 as per the August 2025 Monetary Policy Statement?

questions.question: With reference to the performance parameters of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) for June 2025, which of the following statements is INCORRECT?

options.A: The system-level Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) was robust at 17.44%.
options.B: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio improved to 2.24% compared to 2.67% a year ago.
options.C: The annualised Return on Assets (RoA) and Return on Equity (RoE) stood at 1.34% and 12.70%, respectively.
options.D: The Net Interest Margin (NIM) improved to 3.54% from 3.24% in the corresponding period of the previous year.
options.E: The Net Non-Performing Assets (NNPA) ratio stood at 0.53%.

questions.explanation: All statements are correct except D. The Net Interest Margin (NIM) was 3.24 per cent for June 2025, which is a decrease from 3.54 per cent in June 2024, not an improvement. (Page 11, footnote 29)

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) following its meeting from December 4-6, 2024?

questions.question: In December 2024, the RBI announced a reduction in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) by 50 bps to 4.0 per cent. What is the estimated amount of primary liquidity that this measure is expected to release into the banking system?

questions.question: To enhance credit availability for small and marginal farmers, the RBI has increased the limit for collateral-free agriculture loans. What is the newly enhanced limit per borrower?

questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question:
In a move to attract more capital inflows, the RBI revised the interest rate ceilings on FCNR(B) deposits in December 2024. Which of the following statements regarding this revision is/are correct?
1. The ceiling for deposits with a maturity of 1 year to less than 3 years has been increased to overnight ARR plus 400 bps.
2. The ceiling for deposits with a maturity of 3 to 5 years has been increased to overnight ARR plus 500 bps.
3. The relaxation in interest rate ceilings is available until March 31, 2025.
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct. Banks are permitted to raise fresh FCNR(B) deposits of 1 year to less than 3 years maturity at rates not exceeding overnight Alternative Reference Rate (ARR) plus 400 bps (up from 250 bps). For deposits of 3 to 5 years maturity, the ceiling has been increased to overnight ARR plus 500 bps (up from 350 bps). This relaxation is available till March 31, 2025. (Page 12, 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) through the first half of FY 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent through H1 of FY 2024-25 to align inflation with the target while supporting growth. (Page 2)

questions.question: What is the projected average CPI inflation for the financial year 2024-25?

questions.question: Under the risk assessment scenarios, what is the estimated impact on domestic inflation if international crude oil prices are 10 per cent above the baseline?

options.A: Inflation could be lower by 15 bps
options.B: Inflation could be higher by 15 bps
options.C: Inflation could be higher by 30 bps
options.D: Inflation could be lower by 30 bps
options.E: There would be no significant impact on inflation

questions.explanation: In the scenario assuming crude oil prices to be 10 per cent above the baseline, domestic inflation could be higher by 30 bps, while GDP growth could be weaker by around 15 bps. (Page 20)

questions.question: According to the risk scenarios considered, what is the potential impact on India's real GDP growth if the Indian Rupee (INR) depreciates by 5 per cent over the baseline?

options.A: GDP growth could moderate by 35 bps
options.B: GDP growth could edge up by 25 bps
options.C: GDP growth could moderate by 25 bps
options.D: GDP growth could edge up by 35 bps

questions.explanation: In the scenario where the INR depreciates by 5 per cent over the baseline, inflation could be higher by around 35 bps while GDP growth could edge up by around 25 bps through short-term stimulation of exports. (Page 21)

questions.question: Under the analytical framework presented in Box I.1, what monetary policy action is warranted in a scenario of repeated food inflation shocks coupled with robust aggregate demand conditions?

options.A: A less aggressive monetary policy action due to the transitory nature of shocks.
options.B: No policy response, as monetary policy should look through food inflation.
options.C: A more aggressive monetary policy action to counter compounding effects on core inflation.
options.D: A neutral stance, waiting for supply-side measures to take effect.
options.E: An immediate reduction in the policy rate to support growth.

questions.explanation: Scenario 2 in Box I.1 illustrates that in the event of robust demand conditions, the spike in core inflation from repeated food shocks will be compounded, warranting more aggressive monetary policy action. (Page 22)

questions.question: Under the alternative risk scenarios, what is the estimated impact on domestic inflation if the Indian Rupee (INR) appreciates by 5 per cent relative to the baseline?

options.B: It could moderate by around 35 bps.

questions.question: Which statement accurately reflects the difference between the Reserve Bank's and the Professional Forecasters' median projections for 2024-25 as presented in the report?

options.A: RBI projects higher GDP growth and higher Q4 inflation than forecasters.
options.B: RBI projects lower GDP growth and lower Q4 inflation than forecasters.
options.C: RBI projects higher GDP growth but lower Q4 inflation than forecasters.
options.D: RBI projects lower GDP growth but higher Q4 inflation than forecasters.
options.E: Both have identical projections for GDP growth and inflation.

questions.explanation: Table I.3 shows RBI's projections for 2024-25 as Real GDP growth of 7.0% and Q4 inflation of 4.5%. Professional Forecasters' median projections are 6.7% for Real GDP growth and 4.6% for Q4 inflation. Thus, RBI projects higher growth but slightly lower Q4 inflation. (Page 18, Table I.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the impulse response analysis to a policy rate shock, what is the differential timing of the maximum impact on private consumption (PFCE) versus fixed investment (GFCF)?

options.A: The maximum impact on both is seen around the second quarter.
options.B: The impact on PFCE peaks after two quarters, while for GFCF it peaks around the fifth quarter.
options.C: The impact on GFCF is swifter, peaking in the second quarter, while for PFCE it takes five quarters.
options.D: The maximum impact for both materializes after a full year (four quarters).
options.E: The impact on both is immediate and peaks in the first quarter following the shock.

questions.explanation: The analysis in Box III.1 suggests that private consumption exhibits a swift adverse response, reaching its peak approximately after two quarters following a policy rate shock, while the maximum response of fixed investment is seen around the fifth quarter. (Page 48)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the assessment of risks to baseline projections, what would be the approximate impact on domestic inflation and growth if international crude oil prices are 10 per cent above the baseline?

options.A: Inflation higher by 15 bps and growth weaker by 30 bps.
options.B: Inflation higher by 30 bps and growth weaker by 30 bps.
options.C: Inflation higher by 30 bps and growth weaker by 15 bps.
options.D: Inflation lower by 30 bps and growth stronger by 15 bps.
options.E: Inflation and growth would both be higher by 15 bps.

questions.explanation: The report's analysis on the balance of risks indicates that assuming crude oil prices to be 10 per cent above the baseline, domestic inflation could be higher by 30 bps and growth weaker by around 15 bps, respectively. (Page 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate set by the Monetary Policy Committee in its February 2025 meeting?
questions.explanation: In its February 2025 meeting, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points (bps) to 6.25 per cent. (Page 12-13)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the Reserve Bank's baseline projection for real GDP growth for the financial year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: The report projects real GDP growth at 6.5 per cent in 2025-26, with risks evenly balanced around this baseline path. (Page 20, Table I.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation recorded in February 2025, which was noted as a seven-month low?
questions.explanation: Headline consumer price index (CPI) inflation eased to a seven-month low of 3.6 per cent in February 2025, driven by a sharp decline in vegetable prices inflation. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In December 2024, the Reserve Bank implemented a measure to ease liquidity conditions by reducing the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR). By how many basis points was the CRR reduced?
questions.explanation: In December 2024, the Reserve Bank reduced the cash reserve ratio (CRR) maintained by banks by 50 bps to ease liquidity conditions. (Page 12, 59)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the Reserve Bank's baseline projection for average CPI inflation for the financial year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: According to the Reserve Bank's baseline projections, CPI inflation is projected to average 4.0 per cent in 2025-26. (Page 18, Table I.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the Second Advance Estimates (SAE) by the NSO, what was the estimated real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth for 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The second advance estimates (SAE) released by the national statistical office (NSO) estimated real gross domestic product (GDP) growth at 6.5 per cent year-on-year (y-o-y) in 2024-25. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Headline CPI inflation breached the upper tolerance band in October 2024. What was the inflation rate recorded in that month?
questions.explanation: Headline consumer price index (CPI) inflation increased to 6.2 per cent in October 2024, breaching the upper tolerance band. (Page 11, 25)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the level of capacity utilisation (CU) in the manufacturing sector during Q3:2024-25?
questions.explanation: Capacity utilisation (CU) in the manufacturing sector increased to 75.4 per cent in Q3:2024-25 from 74.7 per cent in the same quarter of the previous year. (Page 51)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What baseline assumption for the price of the Indian basket of crude oil was used for projections for 2025-26?
questions.explanation: The baseline assumption for crude price (Indian basket) is reduced to US$ 70 per barrel during 2025-26, as stated in the April 2025 MPR. (Page 14, Table I.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the survey of professional forecasters, what is the median projection for CPI inflation for Q4 of 2025-26 (y-o-y)?
questions.explanation: The median projections of professional forecasters for year-on-year CPI inflation in Q4 of 2025-26 is 4.5 per cent. (Page 18, Table I.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Real GDP growth in Q3:2024-25 showed an improvement from the previous quarter. What was the y-o-y growth rate recorded in Q3:2024-25?
questions.explanation: Aggregate demand conditions recovered as real gross domestic product (GDP) growth improved to 6.2 per cent (y-o-y) in Q3:2024-25 from 5.6 per cent in the previous quarter. (Page 47, Table III.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Among the quarterly projections for real GDP growth in 2025-26, which quarter is expected to witness the highest growth rate?

options.E: All quarters are projected to have the same growth rate

questions.explanation: The quarterly real GDP growth projections for 2025-26 are: 6.5% in Q1, 6.7% in Q2, 6.6% in Q3, and 6.3% in Q4. Therefore, Q2 is projected to have the highest growth. (Page 20)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the VEC model analysis of factors affecting inflation expectations, which of the following was found to impact the expectations of self-employed and daily workers but not of financial sector employees?

options.C: Share of government expenditure in GDP

questions.explanation: The VEC model results in Box I.1 suggest that crude oil prices are found to impact inflation expectations of self-employed and daily workers only, and not financial sector employees. (Page 16, Table 1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a risk scenario where the Indian Rupee (INR) depreciates by 5 per cent over the baseline, what is the estimated impact on domestic inflation and GDP growth?

options.A: Inflation rises by 50 bps and GDP growth falls by 25 bps
options.B: Inflation rises by 35 bps and GDP growth rises by 25 bps
options.C: Inflation falls by 35 bps and GDP growth falls by 25 bps
options.D: Inflation rises by 25 bps and GDP growth rises by 35 bps

questions.explanation: The report's analysis on the balance of risks indicates that if the INR depreciates by 5 per cent over the baseline, inflation could rise by around 35 bps while GDP growth could benefit by around 25 bps through the trade channel. (Page 22-23)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In February 2025, the contribution of imported components to headline inflation registered a sequential increase. What was the percentage point contribution of these components to the overall headline inflation rate of 3.6 per cent?
questions.explanation: The contribution of imported components to headline inflation was at 21 per cent in February 2025, which translates to a contribution of 0.8 percentage points to the headline inflation rate of 3.6 per cent for that month. (Page 30)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks as of September 2023?
questions.explanation: According to the report, the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks fell to a multi-year low of 3.2 per cent in September 2023. (Page 19, 46)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of September 2023, what was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks?
questions.explanation: The report states that for Scheduled Commercial Banks, the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) stood at 16.8 per cent in September 2023. (Page 19, 63)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Household Net Financial Savings (HNFS) fell sharply in 2022-23 compared to the pandemic peak in 2020-21. What was the HNFS as a percentage of GDP for the year 2022-23?
questions.explanation: Household net financial savings (HNFS) fell sharply to 5.1 per cent of GDP in 2022-23 from 11.5 per cent in 2020-21. This was primarily driven by a rapid rise in financial liabilities. (Page 50)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the Systemic Risk Survey of November 2023, which component of institutional risk saw a marginal increase, moving it into the 'high' risk category?
questions.explanation: The Systemic Risk Survey conducted in November 2023 showed that Cyber risk, a key component of institutional risk, increased marginally and moved up to the ‘high’ risk category. (Page 62, 140)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of bank lending to Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) between June 2021 and June 2023?
questions.explanation: The report highlights that bank lending to NBFCs increased at a CAGR of 26.3 per cent during the past two years (i.e., from June 2021 to June 2023), which was well above the overall bank credit growth. (Page 67)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of the Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFC) sector as of September 2023?
questions.explanation: The CRAR of NBFCs stood at 27.6 per cent in September 2023, which is well above the regulatory minimum of 15 per cent, indicating substantial capital buffers. (Page 19, 71)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following recent regulatory measures to address potential stress in consumer credit, what is the new risk weight on consumer credit exposure for commercial banks, which was increased from 100 per cent?
questions.explanation: To curb potential build-up of stress, the Reserve Bank raised the risk weights on consumer credit exposure of commercial banks to 125 per cent from the previous 100 per cent. (Page 127)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the macro stress tests for credit risk, what is the projected Gross NPA ratio for Public Sector Banks (PSBs) by September 2024 under the severe stress scenario?
questions.explanation: Under the severe stress scenario, the macro stress tests project that the GNPA ratio of Public Sector Banks (PSBs) may swell from 4.4 per cent in September 2023 to 5.1 per cent by September 2024. (Page 91)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the regulatory increase in risk weights on certain consumer credit segments, what is the estimated decline in the banking system's CRAR and CET1 ratio, respectively, in basis points (bps)?
questions.explanation: The report estimates that after adjusting for the increase in risk weights, the CRAR of the banking system (PSBs + PVBs) would decline by 71 bps, and the CET1 ratio would fall by 58 bps. (Page 68)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the macro stress test projections for Scheduled Commercial Banks, what are the anticipated system-level CRAR figures by September 2024 under the medium and severe stress scenarios, respectively?
questions.explanation: The macro stress tests project that the system-level CRAR of 46 major banks may go down to 13.5 per cent in the medium stress scenario and to 12.2 per cent under the severe stress scenario by September 2024. (Page 90)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of September 2024, which was noted as a 12-year low?
questions.explanation: The asset quality of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) improved significantly, with their Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio declining to a 12-year low of 2.6 per cent in September 2024. (Page 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth for India in the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: In the uncertain global environment, the Indian economy is projected to show resilience, with real gross domestic product (GDP) forecasted to grow at 6.6 per cent in 2024-25. (Page 24)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of September 2024?
questions.explanation: The Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks stood at 16.7 per cent in September 2024, which is significantly higher than the regulatory minimum. (Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Provisioning Coverage Ratio (PCR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks improved in September 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: Supported by proactive provisioning, the provisioning coverage ratio (PCR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks improved further to 77.0 per cent in September 2024. (Page 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the November 2024 Systemic Risk Survey (SRS), what percentage of respondents assessed better or similar prospects for the Indian banking sector over a one-year horizon?
questions.explanation: The latest Systemic Risk Survey carried out in November 2024 found that 60 per cent of the respondents assessed better or similar prospects for the Indian banking sector over a one-year horizon. (Page 22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the share of stressed assets, defined as 31-180 days past due (dpd), in the microfinance sector as of September 2024?
questions.explanation: The microfinance sector showed signs of stress, with the share of stressed assets (31-180 days past due) rising from 2.15 per cent in March 2024 to 4.30 per cent in September 2024. (Page 67)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India's weightage in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index (MSCI-EMI) increased significantly by November 2024. What was the new weightage?
questions.explanation: The Indian equity market outperformed its emerging market peers, leading to an increase in India’s weightage in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index (MSCI-EMI) to 19.9 per cent in November 2024. (Page 46)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the macro stress tests for Scheduled Commercial Banks, what is the projected aggregate GNPA ratio by March 2026 under the severe 'adverse scenario 2'?
questions.explanation: The macro stress tests project that the aggregate GNPA ratio of the 46 select banks may rise from 2.6 per cent in September 2024 to 5.3 per cent by March 2026 under the severe 'adverse scenario 2'. (Page 91)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the event of a hypothetical failure of the NBFC with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses, what would be the estimated impact on the total Tier 1 capital of the banking system as of September 2024?

options.A: A solvency loss of 1.80% of Tier 1 capital, leading to the failure of one bank.
options.B: A solvency loss of 2.29% of Tier 1 capital, without any bank failures.
options.C: A solvency loss of 2.74% of Tier 1 capital, without any bank failures.
options.D: A solvency loss of 4.14% of Tier 1 capital, leading to the failure of two banks.
options.E: A solvency loss of 5.06% of Tier 1 capital, without any bank failures.

questions.explanation: Contagion analysis indicates that the hypothetical failure of the NBFC with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses would result in a loss of 2.74 per cent of the banking system's total Tier 1 capital, but it would not lead to the failure of any additional bank. (Page 122)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a sensitivity analysis scenario involving a parallel upward shift of 250 bps in the yield curve, what would be the estimated reduction in the system-level Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) and how many foreign banks would breach the regulatory minimum of 9%?

options.A: A reduction of 77 bps in CRAR, with two foreign banks breaching the minimum.
options.B: A reduction of 114 bps in CRAR, with four foreign banks breaching the minimum.
options.C: A reduction of 115 bps in CRAR, with four foreign banks breaching the minimum.
options.D: A reduction of 318 bps in CRAR, with no banks breaching the minimum.
options.E: A reduction of 608 bps in CRAR, with all foreign banks breaching the minimum.

questions.explanation: It is assessed that a parallel upward shift of 250 bps in the yield curve on the fair-valued portfolio (AFS and FVTPL) would reduce the system-level CRAR by 114 bps. At a disaggregated level, this major shock would cause four foreign banks' CRAR to fall below the regulatory minimum of 9 per cent. (Page 97)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks as of March 2024, which marked a multi-year low?
questions.explanation: As of March 2024, the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks fell to a multi-year low of 2.8 per cent. The Net Non-Performing Assets (NNPA) ratio also fell to 0.6 per cent. (Page 18, 58)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks stood well above the regulatory minimum in March 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: For Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs), the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) stood at 16.8 per cent in March 2024, indicating strong capital buffers. (Page 18)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for India for the fiscal year 2024-25, as stated by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) has projected India's real GDP to grow by 7.2 per cent during 2024-25. This follows a real GDP growth of 8.2 per cent in 2023-24. (Page 34)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the macro stress tests for credit risk, what is the projected Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks by March 2025 under a severe stress scenario?
questions.explanation: The macro stress test results project that the aggregate CRAR of 46 major banks may go down to 13.0 per cent under the severe stress scenario by March 2025, which is still above the minimum capital requirement of 9 per cent. (Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What were the Return on Assets (RoA) and Return on Equity (RoE) for Scheduled Commercial Banks respectively in March 2024, which were close to decadal highs?
questions.explanation: Amidst strong profitability, the Return on Assets (RoA) and Return on Equity (RoE) for Scheduled Commercial Banks remained strong at 1.3 per cent and 13.8 per cent, respectively, in March 2024. (Page 18, 58)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Systemic Risk Survey (SRS) conducted in May 2024 identified several major risks to domestic financial stability. Which of the following risk categories was perceived to have moved from 'medium' to 'high'?
questions.explanation: According to the Systemic Risk Survey in May 2024, risk from equity price volatility was perceived to have moved from the 'medium' to the 'high' risk category. Cyber risk rose but remained within the 'high' category. (Page 71, 120)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the macro stress tests, what is the projected Gross NPA (GNPA) ratio for all Scheduled Commercial Banks by March 2025 in a severe stress scenario?
questions.explanation: While the GNPA ratio of all SCBs is projected to improve to 2.5 per cent by March 2025 under the baseline scenario, it may rise to 3.4 per cent if the macroeconomic environment worsens to a severe stress scenario. (Page 86)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the credit risk sensitivity analysis, what magnitude of shock in terms of standard deviations (SD) to the GNPA ratio would be required to bring the system-level CRAR below the regulatory minimum of 9 per cent?
questions.explanation: The reverse stress test within the credit risk sensitivity analysis shows that a shock of 5.1 standard deviations would be required to bring the system-level Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) below the regulatory minimum of 9 per cent. (Page 87)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the risk parameter disclosures for mutual funds for May 2024, what was the range of days required to liquidate 25% of the portfolio for the top 5 smallcap schemes, and what does this imply about their liquidity risk?

options.A: 4 to 13 days, indicating lower liquidity risk compared to midcap schemes.
options.B: 12 to 36 days, indicating higher liquidity risk compared to midcap schemes.
options.C: 4 to 13 days, indicating higher liquidity risk compared to midcap schemes.
options.D: 12 to 36 days, indicating lower liquidity risk compared to midcap schemes.
options.E: 10 to 20 days, indicating similar liquidity risk as midcap schemes.

questions.explanation: According to the disclosure for May 2024, the time taken to liquidate 25% of the portfolio for the top 5 smallcap schemes ranged from 12 to 36 days. This is longer than the 4 to 13 days required for midcap schemes, indicating higher liquidity risk for smallcap funds. (Page 52)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the contagion analysis as of March 2024, the hypothetical failure of which type of entity would cause the maximum solvency loss to the banking system's total Tier 1 capital?

options.B: The NBFC with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses
options.C: The bank with the maximum capacity to cause contagion losses
options.D: The HFC with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses

questions.explanation: Contagion analysis indicates that if the bank with the maximum capacity to cause contagion losses fails, it would cause a solvency loss of 5.06% of total Tier 1 capital. In comparison, the failure of the top HFC would cause a 3.87% loss, and the failure of the top NBFC would cause a 2.29% loss. Therefore, the failure of the top triggering bank poses the largest solvency risk. (Page 99)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of March 2025?
questions.explanation: According to the performance indicators of SCBs, the CRAR stood at a record high of 17.3 per cent as of March 2025, up from 16.8 per cent in March 2024. (Page 55, Chart 1.44)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the May 2025 Systemic Risk Survey (SRS), what percentage of respondents expressed higher or similar levels of confidence in the Indian financial system?
questions.explanation: The May 2025 Systemic Risk Survey found that respondents remained optimistic about the domestic financial system, with 92 per cent expressing higher or similar levels of confidence. (Page 20, Assessment of Systemic Risk)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the macro stress tests, what is the projected Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks by March 2027 under the 'Geopolitical risk scenario' (Adverse Scenario 1)?
questions.explanation: The macro stress test projects that the aggregate GNPA ratio of 46 major banks may rise from 2.3% in March 2025 to 5.6% by March 2027 under Adverse Scenario 1, which represents a geopolitical risk scenario. (Page 84, Chart 2.11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio for the unsecured retail loan portfolio of Scheduled Commercial Banks as of March 2025?
questions.explanation: The asset quality of unsecured retail loans, while having weakened slightly, showed a GNPA ratio of 1.8 per cent for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of March 2025. (Page 58, Chart 1.48a)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of end-December 2024, what was the approximate level of India's household debt as a percentage of GDP?
questions.explanation: India’s household debt has been increasing, reaching 41.9 per cent of GDP at current market prices as of end-December 2024, although this remains relatively low compared to other Emerging Market Economies (EMEs). (Page 51, para 1.47)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Banking Stability Indicator (BSI) reflects the overall resilience of the banking system. What was the value of the BSI in March 2025, indicating an improvement in stability?
questions.explanation: The Banking Stability Indicator (BSI) improved, with its value decreasing from 0.32 in March 2024 to 0.27 in March 2025, reflecting enhanced resilience of the banking system. (Page 64, Chart 1.59a)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the contagion analysis, what would be the impact on the banking system's total Tier 1 capital from a hypothetical failure of the NBFC with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses?
questions.explanation: The contagion analysis for end-March 2025 shows that the hypothetical failure of the top NBFC with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses would knock off 2.9 per cent of the banking system's total Tier 1 capital. (Page 115, para 2.86 & Table 2.14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the reverse stress test using the cumulative CRAR-depletion curve for March 2025, how many of the top largest borrowers would need to default to cause a depletion of 200 basis points in the system-level CRAR?
questions.explanation: The reverse stress test on credit concentration risk for March 2025 revealed that it would take the default of the top 7, 22, and 46 largest borrowers to deplete the system level CRAR by 100, 200, and 300 basis points, respectively. (Page 88, para 'Reverse stress test...')
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of March 31, 2025, what was the share of loans linked to the External Benchmark-Based Lending Rate (EBLR) within the total retail loan portfolio of All Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs)?
questions.explanation: Table 1.4 on the distribution of retail loans by interest rate framework shows that for All SCBs, 57.5 per cent of the total retail loans were linked to the EBLR framework as of March 31, 2025. (Page 59, Table 1.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the Duration Gap Analysis (DGA) as of March 2025, which of the following correctly describes the impact on the Market Value of Equity (MVE) for Public Sector Banks (PSBs) and Private Sector Banks (PVBs) following a 200 basis points increase in interest rates?

options.A: PSBs' MVE decreases by 1.0%; PVBs' MVE decreases by 2.5%
options.B: PSBs' MVE increases by 1.0%; PVBs' MVE increases by 2.5%
options.C: PSBs' MVE increases by 1.0%; PVBs' MVE decreases by 2.5%
options.D: PSBs' MVE decreases by 2.5%; PVBs' MVE increases by 1.0%
options.E: Both PSBs' and PVBs' MVE decrease by more than 2.0%

questions.explanation: The Duration Gap Analysis revealed contrasting impacts of an interest rate rise on different bank groups. For a 200 bps increase, the MVE for PSBs would be muted with a slight increase of 1.0%, while for PVBs, it would fall by 2.5%. (Page 92, Table 2.6)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the assessment year beginning on April 1, 2025, what is the income tax rate for an individual under the new tax regime for total income up to Rs. 3,00,000?
questions.explanation: As per the revised tax slab table for the assessment year beginning on or after April 1, 2025, under section 115BAC, the rate of tax for total income up to Rs. 3,00,000 is Nil. (Page 52)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the name of the new direct tax dispute resolution scheme introduced in the Finance Bill, 2024?

options.B: Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024

questions.explanation: Chapter IV of the Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024 introduces 'THE DIRECT TAX VIVAD SE VISHWAS SCHEME, 2024'. (Page 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The rate of tax deduction at source (TDS) for e-commerce operators under section 194-O has been revised. What is the new rate?
questions.explanation: Section 61 of the Bill amends section 194-O of the Income-tax Act to substitute the words 'one per cent.' with '0.1 per cent.', effective from the 1st day of October, 2024. (Page 73)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Effective from April 1, 2025, the standard deduction for salaried individuals under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC) has been revised. What is the new deduction amount?
questions.explanation: A proviso has been inserted in section 16(ia) stating that for income-tax computed under section 115BAC, the deduction shall be 'seventy-five thousand rupees' instead of 'fifty thousand rupees'. (Page 39)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance Bill 2024 proposes a new section 194T for deduction of tax at source (TDS) on payments like salary, remuneration, or interest by a firm to its partners. What is the specified TDS rate?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted section 194T mandates that a firm responsible for paying any sum like salary, remuneration, commission, bonus, or interest to a partner shall deduct income-tax at the rate of ten per cent. (Page 73)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The rate of tax deduction at source (TDS) on income by way of commission or brokerage under Section 194H has been reduced. What is the new effective rate from October 1, 2024?
questions.explanation: As per the amendment to section 194H, the words 'five per cent.' have been substituted with 'two per cent.', reducing the TDS rate on commission or brokerage. (Page 72)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge rate applicable to a co-operative society having a total income exceeding one crore rupees but not exceeding ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: For a co-operative society, the surcharge on income-tax is calculated at the rate of seven per cent where the total income exceeds one crore rupees but does not exceed ten crore rupees. (Pages 13, 120)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance Bill 2024 amends the tax rate on short-term capital gains under Section 111A. What is the new tax rate for transfers taking place on or after July 23, 2024?
questions.explanation: Section 111A(1)(i) is amended to state that the tax on such short-term capital gains will be calculated at twenty per cent for any transfer which takes place on or after the 23rd day of July, 2024. (Page 47)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the new tax rate on long-term capital gains under Section 112 for an individual for any transfer that takes place on or after July 23, 2024?
questions.explanation: The amendment to section 112 substitutes the old clauses, specifying a new rate of twelve and one-half per cent for any transfer which takes place on or after the 23rd day of July, 2024. (Page 47)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the newly inserted Section 194T, no TDS is required on payments to a partner if the aggregate sum in a financial year does not exceed a certain limit. What is this threshold?
questions.explanation: Section 194T(2) states that no deduction shall be made if the aggregate of sums credited or paid to the partner does not exceed twenty thousand rupees during the financial year. (Page 73)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new presumptive taxation scheme under section 44BBC has been introduced for non-residents operating cruise ships. What percentage of aggregate receipts is deemed as profits and gains?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted section 44BBC(1) specifies that a sum equal to twenty per cent of the aggregate of specified amounts shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of such business. (Page 41)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For a domestic company with a total income of Rs. 15 crore, what is the applicable rate of surcharge on income tax?
questions.explanation: In the case of every domestic company, a surcharge is calculated at the rate of twelve per cent of such income-tax if the total income exceeds ten crore rupees. (Page 122)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For an individual with a total income of Rs. 3 crore, what is the applicable surcharge rate on income tax?
questions.explanation: For an individual, the surcharge is calculated at the rate of twenty-five per cent of income-tax if the total income exceeds two crore rupees but does not exceed five crore rupees. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, within how many days of receiving the certificate must a declarant pay the determined amount?
questions.explanation: Section 92(2) of the scheme states that the declarant shall pay the amount determined within a period of fifteen days of the date of receipt of the certificate. (Page 87)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the purposes of the Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, what is the 'specified date' on which appeals or applications must be pending?
questions.explanation: Section 89(n) of the scheme defines 'specified date' as the 22nd day of July, 2024. (Page 83)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The rate of tax deduction under section 194DA on sums paid under a life insurance policy has been revised. What is the new TDS rate effective from October 1, 2024?
questions.explanation: The amendment to section 194DA of the Income-tax Act substitutes the words 'five per cent.' with 'two per cent.', reducing the rate of tax deduction. (Page 72)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the assessment year beginning on April 1, 2025, under the revised new tax regime, which income tax rate is applicable for the income slab from Rs. 7,00,001 to Rs. 10,00,000?
questions.explanation: According to the new table under section 115BAC for the assessment year 2025-26, the tax rate for the income slab from Rs. 7,00,001 to Rs. 10,00,000 is 10 per cent. (Page 52)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amended Section 206C(1F), what is the rate of Tax Collected at Source (TCS) for a seller receiving consideration for the sale of a motor vehicle of value exceeding ten lakh rupees?
questions.explanation: The substituted sub-section (1F) of Section 206C specifies that the seller shall collect from the buyer a sum equal to one per cent of the sale consideration as income-tax for the sale of a motor vehicle exceeding ten lakh rupees. (Page 75)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The definition of a 'short-term capital asset' in Section 2(42A) has been amended. With retrospective effect from July 23, 2024, what is the maximum holding period for an asset to be classified as short-term?
questions.explanation: Clause 3 of the Bill amends clause (42A) of section 2 to provide that a 'short-term capital asset' would mean a capital asset held for not more than twenty-four months immediately preceding the date of its transfer, down from thirty-six months. (Pages 33, 162)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For an individual whose income is chargeable under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC), and whose total income includes dividends, what is the maximum rate of surcharge on the income-tax computed on that dividend income?

options.E: The normal applicable surcharge rate without any cap

questions.explanation: A proviso to the surcharge rules for Section 115BAC states that if the total income includes any income by way of dividend or income chargeable under sections 111A, 112, and 112A, the rate of surcharge on the income-tax in respect of that part of income shall not exceed fifteen per cent. (Page 17)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, if a tax arrear relates to disputed interest or penalty for an appellant who filed an appeal on or before January 31, 2020, what percentage of the disputed amount must be paid if the payment is made on or after January 1, 2025?
questions.explanation: The table in Section 90 specifies that for tax arrears related to disputed interest, penalty, or fee where the declarant is an appellant on or before 31st Jan 2020, the amount payable is 35% if paid on or after Jan 1, 2025, but before the last date. (Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the Direct Tax Vivad se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, for an appellant who filed after January 31, 2020, where the tax arrear includes disputed tax, interest, and penalty, what is the amount payable if the payment is made on or before December 31, 2024?

options.A: The amount of the disputed tax
options.E: The aggregate of disputed tax and 10% of disputed tax

questions.explanation: As per the Table under section 90, for a case where the tax arrear is the aggregate amount of disputed tax, interest, and penalty, and the declarant is an appellant after 31st Jan 2020, the amount payable on or before Dec 31, 2024, is simply the 'Amount of the disputed tax'. (Page 84)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For an assessee whose income is taxable under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC), what is the maximum deduction allowed for an employer's contribution to a pension scheme under Section 80CCD(2), effective from April 1, 2025?
questions.explanation: A new proviso in section 80CCD(2) states that for an assessee under section 115BAC, the provision shall have effect as if for 'ten per cent.' referred to in clause (b), the words 'fourteen per cent.' had been substituted, thereby increasing the limit. (Page 44)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amended section 112A, what is the tax rate on long-term capital gains exceeding Rs. 1,25,000 for a transfer taking place on September 15, 2024?
questions.explanation: Section 112A is amended to state that for long-term capital gains exceeding Rs. 1,25,000, the tax rate is twelve and one-half per cent for any transfer which takes place on or after the 23rd day of July, 2024. (Page 49)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the substitution of Section 148, what is the maximum period within which an assessee is required to furnish a return of income after a notice for escaped assessment is issued?

options.A: 30 days from the end of the month of notice
options.B: 60 days from the end of the month of notice
options.C: 90 days from the end of the month of notice
options.D: Three months from the end of the month of notice
options.E: Six months from the end of the month of notice

questions.explanation: The substituted section 148(1) requires the assessee to furnish a return within such period as specified in the notice, which shall not exceed three months from the end of the month in which the notice is issued. (Page 54)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the rate of the "Health and Education Cess on income-tax" to be levied on the amount of income-tax and surcharge?
questions.explanation: As per sub-section (11) of Section 2 of the Finance Bill, the amount of income-tax and surcharge shall be further increased by an additional surcharge called the 'Health and Education Cess on income-tax', calculated at the rate of four per cent. (Page 31)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the assessment year 2025-26, what is the applicable surcharge on income tax for a firm whose total income exceeds one crore rupees?
questions.explanation: In the case of every firm with a total income exceeding one crore rupees, the income tax is increased by a surcharge calculated at the rate of twelve per cent. (Page 13, Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The TDS threshold for rent under section 194-I has been revised. What is the new monthly rent threshold above which tax deduction at source is not required?
questions.explanation: Clause 59 of the Bill amends section 194-I to state that no deduction shall be made if the income by way of rent for a month or part of a month does not exceed fifty thousand rupees. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For resident individuals aged eighty years or more, what is the basic exemption limit for income tax for the assessment year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: For resident individuals aged eighty years or more (super senior citizens), the basic exemption limit where no income tax is charged is up to Rs. 5,00,000. (Page 82)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the applicable income tax rate for a domestic company whose total turnover in the previous year 2022-23 did not exceed four hundred crore rupees?
questions.explanation: For a domestic company where its total turnover or gross receipt in the previous year 2022-23 does not exceed four hundred crore rupees, the rate of income-tax is 25 per cent. of the total income. (Page 86)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amendment to section 194D, what is the revised annual threshold for TDS on income from insurance commission?
questions.explanation: Clause 56 of the Bill amends the second proviso of section 194D, increasing the TDS threshold for insurance commission from fifteen thousand rupees to twenty thousand rupees. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Effective from the assessment year beginning 1st April 2026, what will be the income tax rate for individuals under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC) for the income slab of Rs. 8,00,001 to Rs. 12,00,000?
questions.explanation: Clause 24 amends Section 115BAC, introducing a new tax table. For the income slab from Rs. 8,00,001 to Rs. 12,00,000, the applicable rate of tax is 10 per cent. (Page 46)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the applicable rate of surcharge on income tax for a domestic company with a total income exceeding one crore rupees but not exceeding ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: For a domestic company having a total income exceeding one crore rupees but not exceeding ten crore rupees, the surcharge is calculated at the rate of seven per cent. of such income-tax. (Page 87)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amendment to section 80CCD, what is the maximum annual deduction allowed to a parent or guardian for contributions made to the National Pension Scheme account of a minor?
questions.explanation: Clause 17 inserts a new proviso in section 80CCD(1B) to allow a deduction for payment or deposit made to the account of a minor under the pension scheme, subject to a maximum aggregate amount of fifty thousand rupees. (Page 42, Page 148)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The tax benefit for eligible start-ups under Section 80-IAC has been extended. The benefit will now be available to eligible start-ups incorporated before which date?
questions.explanation: Clause 18 amends the Explanation in Section 80-IAC, extending the date of incorporation for eligible start-ups from '2025' to '2030', meaning the benefit is available to start-ups incorporated before 1st April, 2030. (Page 43, Page 148)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The time limit for furnishing an updated return under Section 139(8A) has been extended. What is the new maximum period from the end of the relevant assessment year within which an updated return can be filed?
questions.explanation: Clause 39 of the Bill amends sub-section (8A) of section 139 to substitute the words 'twenty-four months' with 'forty-eight months', extending the time limit to file an updated return. (Page 50)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance Bill proposes a change in the TDS rate for income in respect of investment in a securitisation trust under Section 194LBC. What is the new uniform TDS rate?
questions.explanation: Clause 63 amends section 194LBC to substitute the varying rates of 25% or 30% with a uniform TDS rate of ten per cent. (Page 57, Page 168)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge rate on income tax for a co-operative society whose total income exceeds ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: In the case of a co-operative society having a total income exceeding ten crore rupees, the surcharge is calculated at the rate of twelve per cent. of such income-tax. (Page 13, Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amended Section 194LA, tax is required to be deducted at source on compensation for compulsory acquisition of immovable property if the aggregate amount of such payments to a resident during the financial year exceeds what revised threshold?
questions.explanation: Clause 62 amends the first proviso to section 194LA, increasing the threshold for no TDS on such compensation from 'two lakh and fifty thousand rupees' to 'five lakh rupees'. (Page 57)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The eligibility period for claiming tax deductions on certain incomes for units in an International Financial Services Centre (IFSC) involved in leasing aircraft or ships under Section 80LA has been extended. What is the new deadline for commencement of operations for such units?
questions.explanation: Clause 19 amends Section 80LA(2)(d) by extending the deadline for commencement of operation for a unit in an IFSC leasing aircraft or ships from 31st March 2025 to 31st March 2030. (Page 43, Page 149)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Where an individual's income is chargeable to tax under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC), what is the maximum rate of surcharge that can be levied on the income tax?
questions.explanation: A proviso to sub-section (6) and sub-section (8) of section 2 states that where the income of a person is chargeable to tax under sub-section (1A) of section 115BAC, the rate of surcharge shall not exceed twenty-five per cent. (Page 19, Page 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For a non-resident company, what is the rate of tax to be deducted at source (TDS) on income by way of royalty payable by an Indian concern, where the agreement was made after 31st March, 1976?
questions.explanation: As per Part II of the First Schedule, for a non-resident company, the TDS rate on royalty income from an agreement made after 31st March 1976 is specified as 20 per cent. (Page 95)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance Bill 2025 provides for retrospective exemption from service tax for reinsurance services provided by insurance companies under which specific schemes?

options.A: Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana and Pradhan Mantri Jeevan Jyoti Bima Yojana
options.B: Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme and Modified National Agricultural Insurance Scheme
options.C: Atal Pension Yojana and National Pension System
options.D: Restructured Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme and Jan Arogya Bima
options.E: Pradhan Mantri Suraksha Bima Yojana and Varishtha Pension Bima Yojana

questions.explanation: Clause 130 of the Bill provides for a special provision for retrospective exemption from service tax for reinsurance services under the Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme and the Modified National Agricultural Insurance Scheme for the period from 1st April, 2011 to 30th June, 2017. (Page 77)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the amendments in Section 140B, what is the additional income tax payable as a percentage of aggregate tax and interest, if an updated return is filed after thirty-six months but before completion of forty-eight months from the end of the relevant assessment year?
questions.explanation: Clause 40 amends Section 140B by inserting a new clause (iv), which specifies that if an updated return is furnished after the expiry of thirty-six months but before completion of forty-eight months, the additional tax will be seventy per cent of the aggregate tax and interest payable. (Page 50, Page 158)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the proposed amendment to Section 87A of the Income-tax Act, what is the new maximum rebate amount available for a resident individual whose total income, chargeable under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC), is up to Rs. 12,00,000?
questions.explanation: Clause 20 amends Section 87A. It substitutes 'seven hundred thousand rupees' with 'twelve hundred thousand rupees' as the income limit and 'twenty-five thousand rupees' with 'sixty thousand rupees' as the rebate amount for individuals under the new tax regime. (Page 43, Page 149)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new presumptive taxation scheme is proposed under Section 44BBD for non-residents providing technology or services for setting up an electronics manufacturing facility in India. What percentage of the aggregate amount paid or received for such services will be deemed as profits and gains?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted section 44BBD(1) specifies that a sum equal to twenty-five per cent of the aggregate amounts (paid, payable, received, or deemed to be received) shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of the non-resident's business. (Page 39)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For contravention of the 'track and trace mechanism' for certain goods under the newly inserted Section 148A of the CGST Act, what is the penalty prescribed under the new Section 122B?

options.A: Rs. 50,000 or 5% of the tax payable, whichever is higher
options.B: Rs. 1,00,000 or 10% of the tax payable, whichever is higher
options.C: Rs. 2,00,000 or 25% of the tax payable, whichever is higher

questions.explanation: The newly inserted section 122B of the CGST Act states that a person who contravenes the provisions of section 148A shall be liable to pay a penalty equal to an amount of one lakh rupees or ten per cent of the tax payable on such goods, whichever is higher. (Page 76)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the case of certain amalgamations of companies or business reorganisations effective on or after April 1, 2025, for how many assessment years can the accumulated loss of the predecessor entity be carried forward in the hands of the successor entity?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted sub-section (6B) in Section 72A and the proviso in Section 72AA state that the accumulated loss shall be carried forward in the hands of the successor entity for not more than eight assessment years immediately succeeding the assessment year for which the loss was first computed for the original predecessor entity. (Pages 41, 147)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the highest surcharge rate applicable on the income-tax calculated on the non-dividend, non-capital gains portion of an individual's income, if their total income exceeds five crore rupees and they have not opted for the Section 115BAC regime?
questions.explanation: For an individual with total income exceeding five crore rupees, the surcharge on income-tax is levied at the rate of thirty-seven per cent. While a proviso caps the surcharge on dividend and certain capital gains income at 15%, the highest rate of 37% applies to the rest of the income. (Page 12, Page 83)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance Bill extends the date of investment for specified persons like sovereign wealth funds and pension funds to claim exemption on certain incomes under section 10(23FE). What is the new deadline by which such investments must be made?
questions.explanation: Clause 6(g) of the Bill amends sub-clause (i) of clause (23FE) of section 10, extending the date of investment for specified persons from '2025' to '2030'. Therefore, the investment must be made on or before 31st March, 2030. (Page 37, Page 142)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's real GDP growth rate in FY24 according to the Provisional Estimates?
questions.explanation: According to the Provisional Estimates, India’s real GDP grew by 8.2 per cent in FY24, marking the third consecutive year of over 7 per cent growth. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The PM-KISAN scheme provides income support to land-holding farmers. What is the total annual financial benefit provided to each eligible farmer family?
questions.explanation: Under the PM-KISAN scheme, an economic benefit of ₹6,000 per year is transferred in three equal four-monthly instalments into the bank accounts of farmers’ families. (Page 378)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's Current Account Deficit (CAD) as a percentage of GDP during FY24?
questions.explanation: The Current Account Deficit (CAD) stood at 0.7 per cent of the GDP during FY24, which was a significant improvement from the 2.0 per cent deficit in FY23. (Page 75)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the approximate retail inflation based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) in FY24?
questions.explanation: After averaging 6.7 per cent in FY23, retail inflation declined to 5.4 per cent in FY24, the lowest level since the Covid-19 pandemic period. (Pages 73, 132)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The PM SVANidhi Scheme, launched in June 2020, was designed to provide financial support to a specific group. Who are the primary beneficiaries of this scheme?
questions.explanation: The PM Street Vendor’s AatmaNirbhar Nidhi (PM SVANidhi) Scheme was launched to facilitate collateral-free working capital loans to street vendors, with over 64 lakh beneficiaries. (Page 331)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) at the end of March 2024?
questions.explanation: Data from the RBI’s Financial Stability Report shows that the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of SCBs declined to a 12-year low of 2.8 per cent in March 2024. (Pages 74, 93)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India's female labour force participation rate (FLFPR) has been on a consistent rise. What was the FLFPR recorded in 2022-23?
questions.explanation: According to the annual PLFS, the female labour force participation rate rose for the sixth consecutive year, reaching 37 per cent in 2022-23 from 23.3 per cent in 2017-18. (Page 79)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the percentage growth in the Gross Value Added (GVA) of the manufacturing sector in FY24?
questions.explanation: The manufacturing sector's GVA grew by 9.9 per cent in FY24, benefiting from reduced input prices and stable domestic demand. (Page 57)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The 'Insurance for all' mission is a key regulatory vision for the insurance sector. By which year does this mission aim to achieve its goal?
questions.explanation: Supported by regulatory measures and the vision to achieve ‘Insurance for all by 2047’, India is poised to emerge as one of the fastest-growing insurance markets. (Page 84)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total capital expenditure of the Union Government for FY24 as per Provisional Actuals?
questions.explanation: The Provisional Actuals show that capital expenditure for FY24 stood at ₹9.5 lakh crore, marking an increase of 28.2 per cent on a YoY basis and 2.8 times the level of FY20. (Page 68)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India witnessed a robust inflow of Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI) in FY24. What was the total value of net FPI inflows during this period?
questions.explanation: Net FPI inflows stood at USD 44.1 billion during FY24, a significant turnaround from the net outflows in the preceding two years, which helped fund the CAD. (Page 75)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) for 2022-23, what percentage of the total workforce is employed in agriculture?
questions.explanation: As per the PLFS, more than 45 per cent (specifically 45.8% as shown in Chart VIII.3) of the workforce is employed in agriculture, highlighting its predominance in providing employment. (Page 321)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Jal Jeevan Mission aims to provide tap water connections to all rural households. As of July 2024, approximately how many rural households have been provided with these connections?
questions.explanation: The Jal Jeevan Mission has successfully provided tap water connections to 11.7 crore households as of July 10, 2024, significantly enhancing the quality of life in rural areas. (Page 255)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The number of Initial Public Offers (IPOs) saw a significant increase in FY24 compared to FY23. What was the total number of IPOs in FY24?
questions.explanation: The number of initial public offers (IPOs) increased by 66 per cent in FY24, rising from 164 in FY23 to 272 in FY24, reflecting a robust primary market. (Page 110)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The PM Vishwakarma scheme, launched in September 2023, provides a stipend to artisans during the basic skill training period. What is the stipend amount provided per day?
questions.explanation: Under the PM Vishwakarma scheme's skill upgradation module, basic skill training is provided with a stipend of ₹500 per day to offset wage loss. (Page 361)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total number of subscribers under the National Pension Scheme (NPS) and Atal Pension Yojana (APY) as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: India's pension sector has expanded significantly, with the total number of subscribers under NPS and APY reaching 735.6 lakh as of March 2024, registering a YoY growth of 18 per cent. (Page 125)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Indian tech start-up ecosystem saw significant activity in 2023. According to NASSCOM, approximately how many new tech start-ups were established during the year?
questions.explanation: As per NASSCOM, the Indian technology start-up sector witnessed the inception of roughly 1,000 new tech start-ups in 2023, taking the total number to approximately 31,000. (Page 395)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following macroeconomic variables did NOT experience a higher Compounded Quarterly Growth Rate (CQGR) in the post-pandemic period (Q3 FY21 – Q4 FY24) compared to the pre-pandemic period (Q1 FY12 – Q4 FY20)?
questions.explanation: Table I.1 shows that the CQGR for all key macroeconomic variables, including GDP, GVA, PFCE, Industrial GVA, Services GVA, and GFCF, was greater in the period Q3 FY21 – Q4 FY24 than in the pre-pandemic period, indicating a strong economic recovery. (Page 63)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the revamped Credit Guarantee Scheme (CGS) for MSEs, several changes were introduced to facilitate additional credit. Which combination of corpus infusion and enhanced credit limit is correct?

options.A: Corpus infusion of ₹5,000 crore; credit limit enhanced to ₹3 crore
options.B: Corpus infusion of ₹7,000 crore; credit limit enhanced to ₹4 crore
options.C: Corpus infusion of ₹9,000 crore; credit limit enhanced to ₹5 crore
options.D: Corpus infusion of ₹10,000 crore; credit limit enhanced to ₹7 crore
options.E: Corpus infusion of ₹12,000 crore; credit limit enhanced to ₹10 crore

questions.explanation: In the Union Budget FY23, the CGS for MSEs was revamped with an infusion of ₹9,000 crore in the corpus of the Credit Guarantee Fund Trust for MSEs, and the credit limit was enhanced from ₹2 crore to ₹5 crore. (Page 92)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the Provisional Actuals for Union Government capex in FY24, which of the following sectors witnessed the highest YoY percentage growth over FY23?
questions.explanation: According to Table I.2, the capex for Railways grew by 52.3% in FY24 (PA) over FY23, the highest among the major sectors listed. Road Transport grew by 28.1%, Transfer to States by 32.5%, and Defence Services by 7.9%. (Page 68)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Regarding the resolution of corporate debtors under the IBC until March 2024, what was the approximate recovery percentage for creditors relative to the liquidation value of the assets?
questions.explanation: In the cases resolved through approved resolution plans under IBC, creditors recovered approximately 32% of their claims, which amounted to a recovery of 162% of the liquidation value of the assets. (Page 99)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The composition of India's merchandise exports shifted between FY23 and FY24. Which statement accurately describes this change?

options.A: The share of consumer goods increased significantly, while capital goods decreased.
options.B: The share of capital goods rose from 16.3% to 18.9%, while consumer goods declined from 48.9% to 47.5%.
options.C: The share of intermediate goods rose, while capital goods remained stagnant.
options.D: The shares of both capital goods and consumer goods saw a substantial increase.
options.E: The shares of both capital goods and consumer goods declined significantly.

questions.explanation: From FY23 to FY24, the share of capital goods in merchandise exports rose substantially from 16.3% to 18.9%. Conversely, the share of consumer goods declined from 48.9% to 47.5%, and intermediate goods also declined from 30.2% to 28.4%. (Page 158)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the sectoral share of factory employment in FY22 is INCORRECT?

options.A: The food products industry was the largest employer with an 11% share.
options.B: Textiles and Wearing Apparel together accounted for a 17% share.
options.C: The Computer, etc. sector had the smallest share among those listed, at 2%.
options.D: Chemicals and Rubber & Plastic sectors each held a 6% share.
options.E: The motor vehicles sector had a larger share than the basic metals sector.

questions.explanation: According to Chart VIII.16, the food products industry was the largest employer (11%). Textiles (10%) and Wearing Apparel (7%) together made up 17%. The Motor Vehicles sector had a 7% share, which is the same as, not larger than, the Basic Metals sector's 7% share. (Page 328)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on NITI Aayog's analysis, approximately how many crore people are estimated to have escaped multidimensional poverty between 2015-16 and 2019-21?
questions.explanation: The analysis shows a sharp decline in multidimensional poverty, with an estimated 13.5 crore Indians escaping it between 2015-16 and 2019-21, putting India on track to achieve SDG Target 1.2 well ahead of 2030. (Page 265)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the estimated real GDP growth for India in FY25, as per the first advance estimates?
questions.explanation: According to the first advance estimates released by the National Statistical Office (MoSPI), the real gross domestic product (GDP) growth for FY25 is estimated to be 6.4 per cent. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (NPAs) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) declined to what 12-year low at the end of September 2024?
questions.explanation: As per the RBI’s Financial Stability Report (December 2024), the gross non-performing assets (NPAs) in the banking system have declined to a 12-year low of 2.6 per cent of gross loans and advances as of September 2024. (Page 74, 84)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above in 2023-24, according to the annual Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS) report?
questions.explanation: The unemployment rate for individuals aged 15 years and above has steadily declined from 6 per cent in 2017-18 to 3.2 per cent in 2023-24, as per the 2023-24 annual PLFS report. (Page 76)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What policy repo rate was maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the RBI during its meetings in the first nine months of FY25 (April-December 2024)?
questions.explanation: During the first nine months of FY25 (April 2024-December 2024), the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the RBI decided to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent. (Page 81)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India's Current Account Deficit (CAD) moderated to what percentage of GDP in Q2 of FY25?
questions.explanation: India's current account deficit (CAD) moderated slightly to 1.2 per cent of GDP in Q2 of FY25, compared to 1.3 per cent in Q2 of FY24. (Page 104)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the estimated growth of Gross Fixed Capital Formation (GFCF) at constant prices for FY25?
questions.explanation: Gross fixed capital formation (GFCF) at constant prices is estimated to grow by 6.4 per cent in FY25. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The total Kharif food grain production for 2024-25 is estimated at a record level. What is this estimated production?
questions.explanation: As per the first advanced estimates of agricultural production for 2024-25, total Kharif food grain production is estimated at a record 1647.05 lakh metric tonnes (LMT). (Page 59, 291)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What growth rate is projected for India's economy in FY26?
questions.explanation: On balance of considerations regarding robust domestic fundamentals and global headwinds, the Economic Survey expects that the growth in FY26 would be between 6.3 and 6.8 per cent. (Page 78)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The services sector growth in FY25 is expected to remain robust. What is the estimated growth rate for the sector?
questions.explanation: Growth in the services sector is expected to remain robust at 7.2 per cent in FY25, driven by healthy activity in various sub-sectors. (Page 57)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the value of the RBI's Financial Inclusion Index at the end of March 2024, indicating significant progress in financial inclusion?
questions.explanation: The government has achieved significant progress in financial inclusion, with the Financial Inclusion Index of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) increasing from 53.9 in March 2021 to 64.2 at the end of March 2024. (Page 80, 88)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Capital-to-Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) stood well above the norm as of September 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: The capital-to-risk-weighted assets ratio (CRAR) for SCBs stands at 16.7 per cent as of September 2024, well above the regulatory norm, indicating robust capital buffers. (Page 74, 84)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP) was launched with a forward-looking approach targeting a projected infrastructure investment of around what amount from FY20 to FY25?
questions.explanation: The National Infrastructure Pipeline (NIP) was launched with a forward-looking approach, targeting a projected infrastructure investment of around ₹111 lakh crore from FY20 to FY25. (Page 209)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the Amrit Bharat Station Scheme, how many railway stations have been identified for redevelopment to enhance amenities?
questions.explanation: Under the Amrit Bharat Station Scheme, aimed at enhancing railway station amenities, 1337 stations have been identified for redevelopment. (Page 212)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The agriculture sector is expected to rebound in FY25. What is the estimated growth rate for the sector?
questions.explanation: On the supply side, the agriculture sector is expected to rebound to a growth of 3.8 per cent in FY25. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Private Final Consumption Expenditure (PFCE) growth at constant prices is estimated to be a key driver of demand in FY25. What is the estimated growth rate for PFCE?
questions.explanation: From the angle of aggregate demand, private final consumption expenditure (PFCE) at constant prices is estimated to grow by 7.3 per cent, driven by a rebound in rural demand. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the estimated growth rate for the industrial sector in FY25?
questions.explanation: The industrial sector is estimated to grow by 6.2 per cent in FY25, supported by strong growth in construction and electricity. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Assets Under Management (AuM) of the mutual fund industry saw remarkable growth, reaching what value as of December 2024?
questions.explanation: The surge in participation and strong market performance led to a remarkable increase in mutual funds’ assets under management (AuM), which rose to ₹66.9 lakh crore as of December 2024. (Page 101)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Bharatmala Pariyojana, launched in October 2017, aims to develop a specific length of National Highways. What is this targeted length?
questions.explanation: The Bharatmala Pariyojana, launched in October 2017, aims to develop 34,800 km of National Highways to improve connectivity and logistics efficiency. (Page 214)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Private Final Consumption Expenditure (PFCE) as a share of GDP reached its highest level since FY03 in FY25. What was this share?
questions.explanation: PFCE as a share of GDP (at current prices) is estimated to increase from 60.3 per cent in FY24 to 61.8 per cent in FY25, which is the highest share recorded since FY03. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its December 2024 meeting, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) announced a cut in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR). What was the quantum of the cut and the expected liquidity infusion?

options.A: Cut to 4.25% from 4.5%, infusing ₹0.96 lakh crore
options.B: Cut to 4.0% from 4.5%, infusing ₹1.16 lakh crore
options.C: Cut to 3.75% from 4.25%, infusing ₹1.25 lakh crore
options.D: Cut to 4.0% from 4.25%, infusing ₹1.00 lakh crore
options.E: Cut to 3.5% from 4.0%, infusing ₹1.36 lakh crore

questions.explanation: In its December 2024 meeting, the MPC announced a cut in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) to 4 per cent of the net demand and time liabilities (NDTL) from 4.5 per cent. The decision is expected to infuse around ₹1.16 lakh crore liquidity into the banking system. (Pages 81-82)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The 'credit-to-GDP gap' is a key indicator of financial cycle stress. How did this gap change for India from Q1 of FY23 to Q1 of FY25?
questions.explanation: With credit growth outpacing nominal GDP growth for two successive years, the credit-GDP gap narrowed significantly to (-) 0.3 per cent in Q1 of FY25 from (-) 10.3 per cent in Q1 of FY23, indicating sustainable credit growth. (Page 87)
questions.subject: General_Awareness
