questions.question: India's share in global IPO listings saw a significant surge in 2024, making it the leading contributor globally. What was the increase in its share compared to 2023?
questions.explanation: India's share in global IPO listings surged to 30 per cent in 2024, up from 17 per cent in 2023, making it the leading contributor of primary resource mobilisation globally. (Page 97)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the fiscal year FY25, the government increased the Minimum Support Price (MSP) for certain crops significantly over the weighted average cost of production. What was the respective MSP increase for arhar and bajra?
questions.explanation: For the fiscal year FY25, the MSP for arhar and bajra has been increased by 59 per cent and 77 per cent over the weighted average cost of production, respectively. (Page 295)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The PM - Surya Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana aims to promote residential rooftop solar capacity. What are the key targets of this scheme?
questions.explanation: The PM - Surya Ghar: Muft Bijli Yojana aims to install rooftop solar plants in one crore households, which is expected to enable approximately 30 gigawatts of residential rooftop solar capacity and contribute to an overall rooftop solar capacity addition of 40-45 gigawatts by 2027. (Page 289)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: At the end of December 2024, the BSE market capitalisation to GDP ratio rose significantly. What was this ratio, indicating a high level of market valuation?
questions.explanation: The BSE market capitalisation to GDP ratio stood at 136 per cent at the end of December 2024, rising significantly over the last 10 years and indicating increased market capitalisation relative to the size of the economy. (Page 100)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Throughout the financial year 2023-24, what was the policy repo rate maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC)?
questions.explanation: Considering the growth-inflation dynamics, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.50 per cent during 2023-24. (Page 29, Para I.14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the Indian economy in the financial year 2024-25, as stated in the report?
questions.explanation: Taking into account factors like favorable agriculture prospects, traction in construction, and investments under the PLI scheme, the real GDP growth for 2024-25 is projected at 7.0 per cent with risks evenly balanced. (Page 34, Para I.38)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the size of the Reserve Bank's balance sheet as a percentage of GDP at the end of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank’s balance sheet size increased to 24.1 per cent of GDP at end-March 2024 from 23.5 per cent at end-March 2023. The balance sheet has normalised to its pre-pandemic level. (Page 68, Para II.4.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the amount of surplus transferred by the Reserve Bank of India to the Central Government for the financial year 2023-24?
questions.explanation: For the financial year 2023-24, the surplus transferred to the Central Government was ₹2,10,873.99 crore. This was a significant increase from the previous year's transfer of ₹87,416.22 crore. (Page 243, Table XII.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: On June 26, 2023, the RBI prescribed a new standardised approach for determining minimum capital requirements for which type of risk, aligning with revised Basel standards?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank prescribed the new standardised approach for determining the minimum capital requirements for operational risk in order to secure greater convergence with the revised Basel standards. This new approach replaces all previously prescribed methods. (Page 145, Para VI.28)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average daily net absorption under the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) during 2023-24, indicating a significant tightening of liquidity conditions?
questions.explanation: Liquidity conditions tightened during 2023-24 in sync with the monetary policy stance. The liquidity surplus as reflected in average daily net absorption under the LAF moderated to ₹485 crore during 2023-24 from ₹1.87 lakh crore in the previous year. (Page 29, Para I.14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework for NBFCs was extended to include certain government NBFCs. From which date will this extension be applicable?
questions.explanation: The Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework, introduced for NBFCs in December 2021, has been extended to government NBFCs (except those in Base Layer) and it would be applicable with effect from October 1, 2024. (Page 31, Para I.24)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the guidelines on Default Loss Guarantee (DLG) in Digital Lending, what is the maximum percentage of the outstanding loan portfolio that a Lending Service Provider (LSP) can guarantee?
questions.explanation: The guidelines on DLG arrangements lay down several regulatory guardrails, including a limit on DLG to five per cent of the outstanding loan portfolio. (Page 143, Para VI.21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: To manage surplus liquidity arising from the return of ₹2000 banknotes, the RBI implemented a temporary Incremental Cash Reserve Ratio (I-CRR). During which period was this measure effective?
questions.explanation: An incremental cash reserve ratio (I-CRR) was applied as a temporary measure during August 12 to October 7, 2023 to absorb the surplus liquidity resulting from the return of ₹2000 banknotes to the banking system. (Page 106, Para III.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In September 2023, RBI issued revised Directions for the classification of investment portfolios of commercial banks. What are the three new principle-based categories introduced?

options.A: Held for Trading, Available for Sale, Held to Maturity
options.B: Held to Maturity, Available for Sale, Fair Value through Profit and Loss
options.C: Held for Trading, Held to Maturity, Not for Sale
options.D: Fair Value, Amortised Cost, Held for Trading

questions.explanation: The revised Directions introduced a principle-based classification of the investment portfolio into three categories: ‘Held to Maturity’ (HTM), ‘Available for Sale’ (AFS), and ‘Fair Value through Profit and Loss Account’ (FVTPL). (Page 145, Para VI.27)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which component is the largest constituent of Reserve Money (RM) with a share of approximately 75.1 per cent in 2023-24?

options.D: Government's currency liabilities to the public

questions.explanation: The growth in currency in circulation (CiC) - the major constituent of RM with a share of 75.1 per cent – decelerated to 4.1 per cent during 2023-24 from 7.8 per cent a year ago. (Page 69, Para II.4.5)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the total amount of gold held by the Reserve Bank of India as of March 31, 2024?
questions.explanation: As on March 31, 2024, the total gold held by the Reserve Bank was 822.10 metric tonnes, an increase from 794.63 metric tonnes on March 31, 2023. (Page 261, Para ii and Table XII.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: To improve compliance culture and promote ethical standards, the RBI issued a final omnibus framework for recognizing Self-Regulatory Organisations (SROs) for its Regulated Entities (REs) on which date?
questions.explanation: A draft of the omnibus framework for SROs was released for comments in December 2023, following which, the final framework was issued on March 21, 2024. (Page 142, Para VI.15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During 2023-24, the pilot for the Central Bank Digital Currency-Retail (e₹-R) was expanded. How many banks and locations did the pilot cover by the end of the year?
questions.explanation: The pilot in the e₹-R segment was expanded to 15 banks and covered 81 locations. Interoperability between UPI and CBDC was also introduced to leverage UPI acceptance infrastructure. (Page 32, Para I.25; Page 151, Para VI.43)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the data on key drivers of liquidity, which of the following factors was the primary driver leading to a net liquidity deficit (injection) of ₹0.76 lakh crore in Q3 2023-24?

options.A: Large net forex purchases by the RBI
options.B: A significant drawdown in Government of India cash balances
options.C: The withdrawal of ₹2000 banknotes from circulation
options.D: Festival-related currency outgo and build-up of government cash balances
options.E: Return of funds from the Incremental Cash Reserve Ratio (I-CRR)

questions.explanation: Liquidity turned into deficit in Q3, with an average net LAF injection of ₹0.76 lakh crore, driven by festival-related currency outgo (withdrawal of Currency in Circulation) in October-November and the build-up of government cash balances in December 2023. (Page 112, Para III.19 and Table III.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During the monetary tightening cycle from May 2022 to March 2024, while the policy repo rate increased by 250 basis points, what was the extent of transmission to the weighted average lending rates (WALR) on fresh and outstanding rupee loans, respectively?

options.A: 250 bps on fresh loans and 250 bps on outstanding loans
options.B: 186 bps on fresh loans and 113 bps on outstanding loans
options.C: 113 bps on fresh loans and 186 bps on outstanding loans
options.D: 167 bps on fresh loans and 113 bps on outstanding loans
options.E: 250 bps on fresh loans and 185 bps on outstanding loans

questions.explanation: During the tightening cycle from May 2022 to March 2024, the WALR on fresh rupee loans rose by 186 bps while that on outstanding loans rose by 113 bps, showing incomplete but significant transmission of the 250 bps repo rate hike. (Page 115, Table III.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the expansion of RBI's balance sheet during FY 2023-24, which asset category witnessed the highest percentage growth?
questions.explanation: The increase on the assets side of the RBI's balance sheet was due to a rise in foreign investments, gold, and loans and advances by 13.90 per cent, 18.26 per cent, and 30.05 per cent, respectively. Loans and Advances saw the highest growth. (Page 243, Para XII.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI harmonised the provisioning norms for standard assets across all tiers of Urban Cooperative Banks (UCBs). For Tier I UCBs, what is the revised uniform provisioning requirement, and by what deadline must they achieve it in a staggered manner?
questions.explanation: The provisioning norms for standard assets applicable to UCBs were harmonised. Tier I UCBs were permitted to achieve the revised requirement of 0.40 per cent as standard asset provisioning vis-à-vis the earlier requirement of 0.25 per cent in a staggered manner by March 31, 2025. (Page 144, Para VI.24)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In response to concerns about 'evergreening' through Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs), what action is mandated for a Regulated Entity (RE) if an AIF scheme it has invested in subsequently invests in a debtor company of that RE?

options.A: Make a 50% provision on the investment and report to RBI within 15 days.
options.B: Immediately exit all investments in any AIFs.
options.C: Liquidate its investment in that specific AIF within 30 days or make a 100% provision.
options.D: Transfer the investment from 'Available for Sale' to 'Held to Maturity' category.
options.E: Obtain a no-objection certificate from RBI to continue the investment.

questions.explanation: To prohibit prudential violations like evergreening, REs were mandated to liquidate their existing investments in AIFs within a stipulated period of 30 days if the AIF scheme had invested or subsequently invests in the RE's debtor company. Failing this, the RE must make a full provision for their investment in that particular scheme. (Page 144, Para VI.26)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The report notes a 'paradoxical' situation where banks simultaneously placed substantial funds under the Standing Deposit Facility (SDF) while borrowing heavily from the Marginal Standing Facility (MSF). What key measure was introduced by the RBI effective December 30, 2023, to address this and improve fund management?

options.A: The spread between MSF and SDF rates was increased.
options.B: A penal charge was introduced for using both facilities on the same day.
options.C: Reversal of liquidity facilities under both SDF and MSF was permitted even on weekends and holidays.
options.D: The borrowing limit under MSF was reduced for banks using the SDF facility.
options.E: Banks were mandated to choose only one of the two facilities on any given day.

questions.explanation: To address the paradoxical situation of simultaneous high usage of both SDF and MSF and to enable better fund management, the RBI decided to allow the reversal of liquidity facilities under both SDF and MSF even during weekends and holidays, effective from December 30, 2023. (Page 113, Para III.22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the Monetary Policy Committee meeting in February 2025, what was the revised policy repo rate?
questions.explanation: The MPC decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent in the February 2025 meeting. (Page 112, 115)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average headline CPI inflation rate during the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Headline inflation moderated to an average of 4.6 per cent during 2024-25 from 5.4 per cent in the previous year. (Page 30, 59)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In December 2024, the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) for banks was reduced to what percentage of Net Demand and Time Liabilities (NDTL)?
questions.explanation: To ease potential liquidity stress, the CRR of banks was reduced by 50 bps to 4.0 per cent of NDTL in December 2024. (Page 112, 116)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth rate in 2024-25, according to the Second Advance Estimates?
questions.explanation: Real gross domestic product (GDP) growth moderated to 6.5 per cent in 2024-25, as per the Second Advance Estimates (SAE) of National Income. (Page 29, 43)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: With effect from April 1, 2025, what is the revised overall Priority Sector Lending (PSL) target for urban co-operative banks (UCBs)?
questions.explanation: The revised PSL guidelines include the revision of the overall PSL target for urban co-operative banks (UCBs) from 75 per cent to 60 per cent, effective from April 1, 2025. (Page 128)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its October 2024 meeting, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to change its policy stance. The stance was changed from what to what?
questions.explanation: In the October 2024 meeting, the MPC unanimously decided to change the policy stance from withdrawal of accommodation to neutral to provide it the flexibility to monitor the progress of ongoing disinflation. (Page 31, 114)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: On May 28, 2024, the RBI launched a unique initiative to capture essential information about FinTech entities and their technology stack. What is this repository called?
questions.explanation: A unique initiative of ‘FinTech Repository’ was launched on May 28, 2024. A related repository for regulated entities called 'EmTech Repository' was also launched simultaneously to capture information on their adoption of emerging technologies. (Page 34, 159)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the eligibility criteria for a Small Finance Bank (SFB) to transition into a Universal Bank, what is the prescribed minimum net worth requirement as at the end of the previous quarter?
questions.explanation: The eligibility criteria for SFBs to transition into universal banks, issued on April 26, 2024, require them to have a minimum net worth of ₹1,000 crore as at the end of the previous quarter. (Page 127)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The revised Prompt Corrective Action (PCA) framework for Urban Co-operative Banks (UCBs) is set to become effective from which date?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank issued the guidelines on the PCA framework for UCBs on July 26, 2024, and its provisions will be effective from April 1, 2025. (Page 128, 165)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During 2024-25, the RBI conducted a suite of market operations to provide durable liquidity. This included a reduction in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) by 50 bps, which was implemented in two tranches effective from which dates?
questions.explanation: The CRR was reduced by 50 basis points (bps) to 4.0 per cent in two equal tranches of 25 bps each with effect from the fortnight beginning December 14, 2024, and December 28, 2024. (Page 116, 278)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the financial year 2024-25, what was the average spread of the Weighted Average Call Rate (WACR) over the policy repo rate?
questions.explanation: The weighted average call rate (WACR), on an average, traded 6 bps above the policy repo rate during 2024-25. (Page 31, 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average daily net absorption under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) during 2024-25, indicating an overall surplus liquidity condition for the year?
questions.explanation: For the year as a whole, liquidity conditions remained in surplus as reflected in average daily net absorption under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) increasing to ₹1,605 crore during 2024-25. (Page 31)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the revised SAARC Currency Swap Framework for 2024-27, what is the total corpus for the newly introduced INR swap window?
questions.explanation: Under the new SAARC currency swap framework 2024-27, an Indian Rupee (INR) swap window has been introduced with various concessions for swap support in INR with a total corpus of ₹250 billion. (Page 210, Box X.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: On June 11, 2024, RBI issued guidelines advising Scheduled Commercial Banks to maintain a uniform turnaround time (TAT) for loans up to ₹25 lakh for micro and small enterprise (MSE) borrowers. What is this uniform TAT?
questions.explanation: Scheduled commercial banks (SCBs) have been advised to have a uniform turnaround time (TAT) of 14 days for loans up to ₹25 lakh for micro and small enterprises (MSE) borrowers to ensure faster disposal of such loan applications. (Page 128, 278)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During the monetary policy tightening cycle from May 2022 to January 2025, by how much did the 1-year median MCLR and repo-linked lending rates (EBLR) of SCBs increase, respectively?
questions.explanation: During the tightening cycle from May 2022 to January 2025, banks revised their repo-linked lending rates upwards by 250 bps and the 1-year marginal cost of funds-based lending rate (MCLR) by 178 bps. (Page 96, Table III.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of December 2024, what was the approximate share of EBLR-linked loans and MCLR-linked loans in the total outstanding floating rate rupee loans of Scheduled Commercial Banks?
questions.explanation: As of December 2024, the proportion of EBLR-linked loans in outstanding floating rate rupee loans of SCBs was 60.6 per cent, while the share of MCLR-linked loans was 35.9 per cent. (Page 97, Table III.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In response to the 25 bps policy repo rate cut in February 2025, how did the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on outstanding rupee loans of SCBs change during the February-March 2025 easing cycle?
questions.explanation: During the easing cycle from February 2025 to March 2025, the WALR on outstanding rupee loans declined by 10 bps in response to the 25 bps repo rate cut, while the WALR on fresh loans increased by 3 bps. (Page 96, Table III.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: To manage liquidity in Q4:2024-25, the RBI announced USD/INR Buy/Sell swap auctions. What were the tenors and total amount for the auctions conducted on January 31, 2025, and those on February 28 & March 24, 2025?

options.A: US$ 5 billion for six months, and US$ 10 billion for one year
options.B: US$ 5 billion for six months, and US$ 10 billion each for three years
options.C: US$ 10 billion for six months, and US$ 5 billion each for three years
options.D: US$ 5 billion for one year, and US$ 10 billion for three years
options.E: US$ 15 billion for six months total

questions.explanation: In Q4:2024-25, the RBI undertook a slew of measures, including a USD/INR Buy/Sell swap auction of US$ 5 billion for a tenor of six months on January 31, 2025, and US$ 10 billion for a tenor of three years each on February 28, 2025 and March 24, 2025. (Page 92, 118)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The reduction of the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) in December 2024 was a key liquidity measure. What was the estimated amount of primary liquidity released into the banking system as a result of this 50 bps reduction?
questions.explanation: The reduction of CRR to 4.0 per cent on December 6, 2024, was done in two tranches. This reduction released primary liquidity of about ₹1.16 lakh crore to the banking system. (Page 116)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The report highlights a difference in monetary policy transmission across bank groups. During the May 2022-January 2025 tightening cycle, the WALR on outstanding rupee loans for Public Sector Banks (PSBs) saw lower transmission compared to Private Sector Banks (PVBs) primarily due to:

options.A: PSBs having a higher proportion of EBLR-linked loans.
options.B: PSBs having a comparatively higher share of internal benchmark-based loans like MCLR.
options.C: PVBs being slower to adjust their deposit rates.
options.D: PSBs benefiting more from low-cost deposits.
options.E: Foreign banks having the lowest transmission rate.

questions.explanation: The transmission to WALR on outstanding rupee loans was lower for PSBs, reflecting a comparatively higher share of internal benchmark-based lending rates, viz., MCLR and others in their portfolios, which have longer reset periods. (Page 97)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the value of the Reserve Bank of India’s Financial Inclusion Index (FI-Index) as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank of India’s Financial Inclusion Index (FI-Index), which captures the extent of financial inclusion across the country, stood at 64.2 in March 2024, an increase from 60.1 in March 2023. (Page 24)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation rate recorded in February 2025, which marked a seven-month low?
questions.explanation: Headline CPI inflation moderated to a seven-month low of 3.6 per cent in February 2025, declining from 4.3 per cent in January 2025, on account of a correction in food prices. (Page 31, 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the findings of the sixth round of India's remittances survey for 2023-24, which state emerged as the top recipient of inward remittances?
questions.explanation: According to the state-wise destination of remittances in 2023-24, Maharashtra received the largest share at 20.5 per cent, followed by Kerala with a 19.7 per cent share. (Page 100, Table 2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the approximate number of complaints received under the RBI’s Integrated Ombudsman Scheme in the financial year 2023-24?
questions.explanation: The number of complaints received under the RBI’s Integrated Ombudsman Scheme increased at a compounded average growth rate of almost 50 per cent per year over the last two years to reach 9.34 lakh in 2023-24. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the 2023-24 data from the sixth round of the remittances survey, what was the approximate combined share of the top three source countries (United States, United Arab Emirates, and United Kingdom) in India's total inward remittances?
questions.explanation: The top three source countries for India's inward remittances in 2023-24 were the United States (27.7%), United Arab Emirates (19.2%), and the United Kingdom (10.8%). Their combined share is 27.7% + 19.2% + 10.8% = 57.7%, which is approximately 58%. (Page 99, Table 1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation rate recorded for June 2025?
questions.explanation: According to the 'State of the Economy' article, headline inflation, as measured by y-o-y changes in the all-India consumer price index (CPI), declined to 2.1 per cent in June 2025. This was the lowest rate since January 2019. (Page 44)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of June 2025, what percentage of India's installed power capacity was accounted for by non-fossil fuel sources, achieving a key energy transition milestone five years ahead of schedule?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article highlights that as of June 2025, non-fossil fuel sources accounted for 50.1 per cent of India’s installed power capacity, achieving the target of 50 per cent five years ahead of the 2030 schedule. (Page 43)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the final quarter of the financial year 2024-25, India's current account balance recorded a surplus. What was the value of this surplus?
questions.explanation: The section on Balance of Payments in the 'State of the Economy' article states that India’s current account balance recorded a surplus of US$ 13.5 billion (1.3 per cent of GDP) in Q4:2024-25. (Page 54)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the year-on-year credit growth of scheduled commercial banks as recorded on June 27, 2025?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article mentions that the credit growth of scheduled commercial banks accelerated to 10.4 per cent (y-o-y) as on June 27, 2025, up from 9.9 per cent a month ago. (Page 50)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on an empirical analysis presented in the bulletin regarding the oil price and inflation nexus, what would be the approximate contemporaneous impact on India's headline inflation if international crude oil prices were to rise by 25%?
questions.explanation: The article 'Revisiting the Oil Price and Inflation Nexus in India' concludes that a 10 per cent increase in international crude oil prices could raise India’s headline inflation by around 20 basis points. Therefore, a 25% rise would lead to an increase of (25/10) * 20 = 50 basis points. (Page 74)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio for banks as of the end of June 2024, which was noted as the lowest since March 2011?
questions.explanation: According to the bulletin, the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of banks was 2.7 per cent at end-June 2024, marking its lowest level since the end of March 2011. (Page 12, Footnote 14)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the first quarter of FY 2024-25, what was the growth rate of Private Final Consumption Expenditure (PFCE), which accelerated to a seven-quarter high?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article states that Private final consumption expenditure (PFCE) growth accelerated to a seven-quarter high of 7.4 per cent in Q1:2024-25, driven by resilient urban demand and improving rural demand conditions. (Page 79)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the value of the RBI's Financial Inclusion Index (FI-Index) as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: In the speech 'FinTech Innovations for India @100', it is mentioned that the Reserve Bank’s Financial Inclusion Index rose to 64.2 in March 2024 from 53.9 in March 2021. (Page 22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of March 31, 2024, what was the total outstanding credit from Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) to the non-conventional energy sector?
questions.explanation: The 'State of the Economy' article mentions that as of March 31, 2024, scheduled commercial banks' (SCBs') credit limits for the non-conventional energy sector stood at ₹1.19 lakh crore with a total outstanding of ₹75,251 crore. (Page 81)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which recent RBI initiative in the FinTech space aims to create an end-to-end digital platform that enables a seamless, consent-based flow of information from multiple data service providers to lenders, with a particular focus on improving credit access for agricultural and MSME borrowers?

options.A: The framework for Self-Regulatory Organisations for FinTech (SRO-FT)
options.B: The pilot project for programmable Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC)
options.D: The Regulatory Sandbox cohort on MSME lending

questions.explanation: The Unified Lending Interface (ULI), previously known as the Public Tech Platform for Frictionless Credit (PTPFC), is designed to facilitate a seamless, consent-based flow of digital information from various data providers to lenders. This is expected to significantly reduce credit appraisal times, particularly for agricultural and MSME borrowers. (Pages 16, 22, 29)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the unemployment rate in India during 2023-24, as noted in the recent economic review?
questions.explanation: According to the document, the unemployment rate in India improved to 3.2 per cent during 2023-24, a significant decrease from 6% in 2017-18. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the central government's budgeted fiscal deficit to GDP ratio for the fiscal year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: The document states that the central government's fiscal deficit to GDP ratio declined to 4.8 per cent in 2024-25 and is budgeted to moderate further to 4.4 per cent in 2025-26. (Page 9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: At the end of December 2024, what was the Capital to Risk-Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) of Scheduled Commercial Banks?
questions.explanation: Footnote 2 on page 8 mentions that the capital to risk-weighted assets (CRAR) of scheduled commercial banks stood at 16.5 per cent at the end of December 2024. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As announced in the Union Budget 2025, what is the revised Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) cap proposed for the Insurance sector?
questions.explanation: Footnote 1 on page 7 explicitly states that as announced in the Union Budget 2025, the FDI cap in the Insurance sector will rise to 100 per cent, with the condition that the entire premium is invested within India. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: While Gross FDI inflows to India saw a significant increase in April-February 2024-25 compared to the previous year, what was the primary reason cited for the moderation in Net FDI inflows during the same period?

options.A: A sharp decline in confidence from foreign investors due to global volatility.
options.B: Increased government restrictions on foreign capital repatriation.
options.C: Higher repatriation of capital by foreign investors and increased outward investment from India.
options.D: A significant fall in services exports, reducing the available capital for investment.
options.E: The appreciation of the Indian Rupee making new investments less attractive.

questions.explanation: The document states on page 8 that 'Net FDI inflows, however, moderated during this period due to higher repatriations and outward investment, which is a sign of a mature market where foreign investors can enter and exit smoothly, reflecting positively on the Indian economy.' This indicates that the moderation was not due to negative sentiment but rather a characteristic of a maturing market. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) meeting held from April 7 to 9, 2025, what was the policy repo rate set at?
questions.explanation: In its meeting in April 2025, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points to 6.00 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of April 4, 2025, what was the level of India's foreign exchange reserves?
questions.explanation: The document states that as on 4th April, 2025, India’s foreign exchange reserves stood at 676.3 billion US dollars, providing an import cover of about 11 months. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following policy measures was proposed to expand the scope of co-lending arrangements?

options.A: Restricting co-lending to only large infrastructure projects between Banks and NBFCs.
options.B: Limiting the framework to priority sector loans but including all regulated entities.
options.C: Extending the arrangements to all regulated entities and for all types of loans, not just priority sector.
options.D: Introducing a new framework for co-lending exclusively between small finance banks and co-operative banks.
options.E: Discontinuing the co-lending framework in favour of securitisation of stressed assets.

questions.explanation: The bulletin proposes to extend the extant co-lending guidelines, which are currently applicable only to arrangements between banks and NBFCs for priority sector loans, to all regulated entities and for all types of loans, both priority sector and otherwise. (Pages 11, 19)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial soundness parameters for December 2024, which of the following statements provides the most accurate comparison between the banking sector and the NBFC sector?

options.A: The banking sector's Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio was higher than that of the NBFC sector.
options.B: The NBFC sector's Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) was lower than the system-level CRAR of the banking sector.
options.C: Both the banking sector and the NBFC sector witnessed a deterioration in their GNPA ratios compared to December 2023.
options.D: While the Return on Assets (RoA) for the NBFC sector showed a year-on-year decrease from December 2023, a similar year-on-year trend for the banking sector's RoA is not provided.
options.E: The Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) for the NBFC sector was reported to be well above the regulatory threshold at 130 per cent.

questions.explanation: Footnote 26 on page 11 explicitly states that the RoA for NBFCs decreased from 3.11% in December 2023 to 2.86% in December 2024. In contrast, Footnote 25, which details the banking sector's profitability indicators, only provides the figures for December 2024 (RoA at 1.37%) without a year-on-year comparison. This makes statement D the most accurate observation. A is incorrect (Banking GNPA 2.42% < NBFC GNPA 2.53%). B is incorrect (Banking CRAR 16.43% < NBFC CRAR 26.22%). C is incorrect as both improved. E is incorrect as the 130% LCR is for the banking sector. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decide regarding the policy repo rate in its meeting held from October 7-9, 2024?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee, by a majority of 5 out of 6 members, decided to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.50 per cent. This decision was taken after assessing the evolving macroeconomic and financial conditions. (Page 7)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the Reserve Bank of India's projection for real GDP growth for the financial year 2024-25, as stated in the October 2024 bulletin?
questions.explanation: Taking various factors into consideration, including consumption and investment demand, the real GDP growth for 2024-25 is projected at 7.2 per cent. The quarterly projections are Q2 at 7.0%, Q3 at 7.4%, and Q4 at 7.4%. (Page 9)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the October 2024 Statement on Developmental and Regulatory Policies, what was the announced enhancement for the UPI Lite wallet limit?
questions.explanation: To encourage wider adoption of UPI, it was decided to increase the UPI Lite wallet limit from ₹2,000 to ₹5,000 and the per-transaction limit from ₹500 to ₹1,000. (Pages 14, 22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected CPI inflation for the financial year 2024-25 according to the Governor's Statement in the October 2024 bulletin?
questions.explanation: Taking into account various factors including food price momentum and global commodity prices, the CPI inflation for 2024-25 is projected at 4.5 per cent, with risks evenly balanced. (Page 10)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following statements accurately describes the Monetary Policy Committee's (MPC) decision regarding its stance in the October 2024 meeting?

options.A: The MPC unanimously decided to change the stance to 'calibrated tightening' to preemptively address rising core inflation.
options.B: The MPC changed the stance from 'withdrawal of accommodation' to 'neutral' with a 5-1 majority to support domestic growth.
options.C: The MPC unanimously decided to change the monetary policy stance from 'withdrawal of accommodation' to 'neutral' to provide flexibility in monitoring disinflation.
options.D: The MPC maintained the stance of 'withdrawal of accommodation' by a unanimous vote to ensure inflation aligns with the target.
options.E: The MPC changed the stance from 'accommodative' to 'neutral' to address risks from volatile international crude oil prices.

questions.explanation: The MPC unanimously decided to change the stance to 'neutral' from 'withdrawal of accommodation'. The rationale provided was that this change offers flexibility to the MPC while enabling it to monitor the progress on disinflation which is still incomplete. This is distinct from the 5-1 majority vote on keeping the repo rate unchanged. (Pages 7, 18)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: During its meeting from June 4-6, 2025, what did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decide to set the policy repo rate at?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 50 basis points to 5.50 per cent with immediate effect. (Page 7, Page 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the financial year 2025-26, what has the CPI inflation been projected at?
questions.explanation: Assuming a normal monsoon, CPI inflation for the financial year 2025-26 is now projected at 3.7 per cent, with quarterly projections of Q1 at 2.9%, Q2 at 3.4%, Q3 at 3.9%, and Q4 at 4.4%. (Page 10, Page 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What significant change regarding the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) was announced to be implemented in a staggered manner starting September 2025?

options.A: An increase of 50 bps to 4.5% of NDTL
options.B: A reduction of 100 bps to 3.0% of NDTL
options.C: A reduction of 50 bps to 3.5% of NDTL
options.D: An increase of 100 bps to 5.0% of NDTL

questions.explanation: To further provide durable liquidity, it has been decided to reduce the cash reserve ratio (CRR) by 100 basis points (bps) to 3.0 per cent of net demand and time liabilities (NDTL) in a staggered manner during the course of the year. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: While gross Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) inflows to India increased by approximately 14 per cent in 2024-25, net FDI inflows saw a significant moderation. Which of the following best explains this divergence?

options.A: A sharp increase in Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI) outflows, which offset the FDI inflows.
options.B: A rise in repatriation by foreign investors and an increase in outward FDI from India.
options.C: The current account deficit widening to unsustainable levels, deterring net investment.
options.D: A decrease in net inflows under external commercial borrowings (ECBs).
options.E: A reclassification of certain capital flows from FDI to FPI by the authorities.

questions.explanation: The document states that the moderation in net FDI inflows is on account of a rise in repatriation and net outward FDI, even while gross FDI inflows actually increased by 14 per cent. (Page 10, Footnote 30)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the Monetary Policy Committee meeting from February 5-7, 2025, what was the policy repo rate adjusted to?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously decided to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent. (Page 8)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation rate for January 2025, which marked a five-month low?
questions.explanation: Headline CPI inflation moderated to a five-month low of 4.3 per cent in January 2025 from 5.2 per cent in December 2024, mainly due to a sharp decline in vegetable prices. (Page 29, 51)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: To combat cyber security threats like phishing and enhance trust in digital banking, which exclusive internet domain is the RBI introducing for Indian banks starting from April 2025?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank of India is introducing the 'bank.in' exclusive Internet Domain for Indian banks to reduce cyber security threats. The actual registrations will commence from April 2025, and this will be followed by a 'fin.in' domain for the wider financial sector. (Page 11, 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Considering the monetary policy tightening period from May 2022 to December 2024, where the policy repo rate was hiked by 250 basis points, which of the following statements accurately reflects the transmission to banks' deposit and lending rates?

options.A: The increase in the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans was greater than the increase in the 1-year median MCLR.
options.B: The transmission to the Weighted Average Domestic Term Deposit Rate (WADTDR) on fresh deposits was greater than the policy repo rate hike.
options.C: The WALR on outstanding rupee loans increased by more than the WADTDR on outstanding deposits.
options.D: The increase in the 1-year median MCLR was exactly half of the policy repo rate hike.
options.E: The transmission to fresh deposits and fresh loans was identical in magnitude.

questions.explanation: During the tightening period from May 2022 to December 2024, in response to the 250 bps policy rate hike, the WADTDR on fresh deposits increased by 254 bps, which is greater than the policy rate hike itself. In contrast, the WALR on fresh loans increased by 174 bps (less than the 1-year MCLR increase of 178 bps), and the WALR on outstanding loans increased by 115 bps (less than the WADTDR on outstanding deposits increase of 197 bps). (Page 61, Table IV.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the real GDP growth projected by the Reserve Bank of India for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: For the current year (2024-25), the Reserve Bank of India has projected real GDP growth of 7.2 per cent, with risks evenly balanced around this forecast. This is supported by improving domestic demand and a strong services sector. (Source: Page 20, 27)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's foreign exchange reserve position as on October 31, 2024, making it the fourth largest in the world?
questions.explanation: The document states that India has the fourth largest foreign exchange reserves in the world at US$ 682 billion as on October 31, 2024, sufficient to cover the entire external debt and about 12 months of merchandise imports. (Source: Page 15)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Unified Payments Interface (UPI) transactions reached a new milestone in October 2024. What was the record volume of transactions achieved during that month?
questions.explanation: The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) hit a milestone of 16.6 billion transactions in a month in October 2024, with improvements in its capabilities like successful instant debit reversals. (Source: Page 32, 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In its meeting held from October 7-9, 2024, what change did the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) make to its monetary policy stance?

options.B: From accommodative to withdrawal of accommodation
options.C: From withdrawal of accommodation to neutral
options.E: No change was made to the stance

questions.explanation: The MPC, in its meeting on October 7-9, 2024, took note of the prevailing inflation-growth dynamics and decided to change the monetary policy stance from 'withdrawal of accommodation' to 'neutral'. (Source: Page 13)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial soundness indicators for banks in India at the end of June 2024, which of the following combinations of Gross NPA ratio, Net NPA ratio, and Capital Adequacy Ratio is correct?

options.A: Gross NPA: 2.5%, Net NPA: 0.6%, Capital Adequacy: 16.7%
options.B: Gross NPA: 2.7%, Net NPA: 0.6%, Capital Adequacy: 16.7%
options.C: Gross NPA: 2.7%, Net NPA: 0.8%, Capital Adequacy: 16.5%
options.D: Gross NPA: 2.9%, Net NPA: 0.7%, Capital Adequacy: 17.1%
options.E: Gross NPA: 2.5%, Net NPA: 0.5%, Capital Adequacy: 16.9%

questions.explanation: According to the bulletin, at the end of June 2024, Gross non-performing assets were 2.7 per cent of total assets, the net non-performing asset ratio was 0.6 per cent, and banks in India maintained a capital ratio of 16.7 per cent. (Source: Page 27)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation rate recorded for December 2024?
questions.explanation: According to the bulletin, headline inflation, as measured by y-o-y changes in the all-India consumer price index (CPI), eased to a four-month low of 5.2 per cent in December 2024 from 5.5 per cent in November 2024. (Page 29)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the real GDP growth rate for FY 2024-25 as per the first advance estimates released by the National Statistics Office (NSO)?
questions.explanation: The first advance estimates (FAE) of national income, released on January 7, 2025, placed the real GDP growth for 2024-25 at 6.4 per cent. This was a moderation from the 8.2 per cent growth recorded a year ago. (Page 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) processed a daily average of how many transactions in December 2024?
questions.explanation: The bulletin highlights that the Unified Payments Interface (UPI) showcased its scalability by processing 54 crore daily average transactions in December 2024, a significant increase from 39 crore in December 2023. (Page 48)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the net Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) inflow recorded during the period of April-November 2024?
questions.explanation: Net FDI declined significantly to US$ 0.5 billion during April-November 2024, a sharp drop from the US$ 8.5 billion recorded in the same period a year ago. This was due to a rise in repatriation and net outward FDI. (Page 43)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the first advance estimates for 2024-25, what was the estimated positive contribution of net exports to the overall GDP growth?
questions.explanation: The bulletin states that on the external front for FY 2024-25, exports grew by 5.9 per cent while imports contracted by 1.3 per cent. This dynamic enabled net exports to contribute positively to GDP growth by 1.7 percentage points. (Page 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) in its meeting held from August 4-6, 2025?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) unanimously voted to keep the policy repo rate under the liquidity adjustment facility (LAF) unchanged at 5.50 per cent.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the projected CPI headline inflation for the financial year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: Considering all factors, the CPI inflation for 2025-26 is projected at 3.1 per cent, with quarterly projections of 2.1% for Q2, 3.1% for Q3, and 4.4% for Q4.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI announced an expansion of functionality in its Retail Direct platform. What new facility was enabled for retail investors to systematically plan their investments in Treasury bills (T-bills)?

options.A: Integration with UPI for instant payments
options.B: Introduction of a mobile application for G-Secs
options.C: Facility for investing in Sovereign Gold Bonds
options.D: Auto-bidding facility for investment and re-investment
options.E: Standardisation of settlement procedures for deceased customers

questions.explanation: An auto-bidding facility for Treasury bills (T-bills), covering both investment and re-investment options, has been enabled in Retail Direct. This new functionality helps investors to mandate automatic placement of bids in primary auctions of T-bills.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Governor's Statement noted that CPI headline inflation declined for the eighth consecutive month in June 2025. What was this 77-month low figure?
questions.explanation: The bulletin states that CPI headline inflation declined for the eighth consecutive month to a 77-month low of 2.1 per cent in June 2025.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the financial stability assessment, which of the following sets of parameters for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of June 2025 is correctly reported?
questions.explanation: Footnote 29 on page 11 provides the key parameters for SCBs as of June 2025: the GNPA ratio was 2.24 per cent, the NNPA Ratio was 0.53 per cent, and the Capital to Risk Weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) was 17.44 per cent. The other options either use data from June 2024 or mix SCB data with NBFC data.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In December 2024, the Reserve Bank of India announced an enhancement in the limit for collateral-free agriculture loans. What is the new limit per borrower?
questions.explanation: Taking into account the rise in agricultural input costs and overall inflation, the RBI decided to increase the limit for collateral-free agriculture loans from ₹1.6 lakh to ₹2 lakh per borrower to enhance credit availability for small and marginal farmers. (Page 13, 22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projection for real GDP growth for the fiscal year 2024-25, as stated in the RBI's December 2024 Monetary Policy Statement?
questions.explanation: Taking various domestic and global factors into consideration, the Monetary Policy Committee projected the real GDP growth for 2024-25 at 6.6 per cent. (Page 9, 17)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The RBI announced a reduction in the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) in its December 2024 policy statement, which is expected to release primary liquidity of about ₹1.16 lakh crore. What is the final CRR after this reduction?
questions.explanation: It was decided to reduce the cash reserve ratio (CRR) of all banks by 50 bps in two equal tranches of 25 bps each, with effect from the fortnights beginning December 14 and December 28, 2024. This will restore the CRR to 4.0 per cent of NDTL. (Page 11, 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the financial stability data released in the bulletin, the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) reached its lowest level since March 2011. What was this ratio as at the end of September 2024?
questions.explanation: The gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks improved further and was 2.54 per cent as at end-September 2024, which is the lowest since March 2011. (Page 11, Footnote 37)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the December 2024 Statement on Developmental and Regulatory Policies, the RBI introduced several measures. Which of the following correctly pairs a new initiative with its primary objective?

options.A: MuleHunter.AI™ : To create an ethical framework for Artificial Intelligence in finance.
options.B: Secured Overnight Rupee Rate (SORR) : To increase the limit on collateral-free agriculture loans.
options.C: 'Connect 2 Regulate' : To link the FX-Retail platform with Bharat Connect for enhanced user access.
options.D: Pre-sanctioned Credit Lines through UPI : To permit Small Finance Banks to offer this facility, enhancing formal credit for 'new to credit' customers.
options.E: Framework for Responsible and Ethical Enablement of AI (FREE-AI) : To develop an AI/ML model to identify and reduce digital frauds via mule accounts.

questions.explanation: The RBI decided to permit Small Finance Banks (SFBs) to extend pre-sanctioned credit lines through the UPI to deepen financial inclusion and enhance formal credit, particularly for 'new to credit' customers. The other options incorrectly match the initiatives with their objectives: MuleHunter.AI is for identifying mule bank accounts, SORR is a new benchmark rate, 'Connect 2 Regulate' is an initiative for open regulation, and FREE-AI is the committee for creating an AI framework. (Page 13, 22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate maintained by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) throughout the first half of FY 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent through H1 (first half) of 2024-25 in its meetings held in April, June, and August 2024.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the real GDP growth projected by the RBI for the fiscal year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The report states that real GDP growth is expected at 7.2 per cent in 2024-25, with risks evenly balanced around the baseline.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the average CPI inflation projected by the RBI for the fiscal year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: According to the report, CPI inflation is projected to average 4.5 per cent in 2024-25, with risks evenly balanced.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In Q1:2024-25, which major component of aggregate demand recorded a year-on-year contraction?
questions.explanation: As per Table III.1 on Real GDP Growth, Government Final Consumption Expenditure (GFCE) contracted by 0.2 per cent (y-o-y) in Q1:2024-25.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In May 2024, core inflation (CPI excluding food & fuel) fell to its lowest level since the beginning of the current CPI series in January 2012. What was this level?
questions.explanation: The report mentions that core inflation fell to its lowest level of 3.1 per cent in the current series (since January 2012) in May 2024.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What price for the Indian basket of crude oil has been assumed in the RBI's baseline projections for H2:2024-25?
questions.explanation: Table I.2, 'Baseline Assumptions for Projections', indicates that the price of crude oil (Indian basket) is assumed at US$ 80 per barrel during H2:2024-25.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks declined to what level in June 2024?
questions.explanation: The asset quality of Scheduled Commercial Banks improved, with the overall gross non-performing assets (NPA) ratio declining to 2.7 per cent in June 2024 from 3.7 per cent a year ago.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the average food price inflation during the first five months (April-August 2024) of the fiscal year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The report states that food price inflation remained elevated, averaging 6.9 per cent over the last five months (April-August 2024).
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the monetary policy tightening cycle from May 2022 to August 2024, the policy repo rate increased cumulatively by 250 basis points. By how much did the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans of SCBs increase during the same period?
questions.explanation: As per Table IV.4 on monetary policy transmission, during the tightening period from May 2022 to August 2024, the WALR on fresh rupee loans increased by 190 basis points.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the seasonally adjusted capacity utilisation in the manufacturing sector in Q1:2024-25, which was noted to be well above the long-term average?
questions.explanation: The report mentions that seasonally adjusted capacity utilisation improved from 74.6 to 75.8 per cent in Q1:2024-25 and is well above the long-term average of 73.8 per cent.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the majority vote in the August 2024 MPC meeting to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent?
questions.explanation: The report states that in the August 2024 meeting, the MPC decided by a majority of 4-2 to keep the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.5 per cent.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Considering the risk scenarios presented, a simultaneous 5% depreciation of the INR and a 10% rise in international crude oil prices above the baseline would likely increase headline inflation by approximately how many basis points?
questions.explanation: According to the risk scenarios, a 5% INR depreciation could increase inflation by around 35 bps, and a 10% rise in crude oil prices could increase it by 30 bps. The combined approximate impact would be 65 bps.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: How did the median projection for the end-period repo rate for 2024-25 from the Survey of Professional Forecasters (SPF) compare with the actual policy rate maintained by the MPC as of the October 2024 report?

options.A: SPF projected a 25 bps higher rate.
options.B: SPF projected a 25 bps lower rate.
options.C: SPF projection was identical to the MPC's rate.
options.D: SPF projected a 50 bps lower rate.
options.E: SPF did not provide a repo rate projection.

questions.explanation: Table I.3 shows the median projection from the SPF for the end-period repo rate for 2024-25 is 6.25%. The MPC maintained the rate at 6.50%. Therefore, the SPF projected a rate 25 bps lower than the prevailing rate.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the RBI's quarterly projections for 2024-25, in which quarter is CPI inflation expected to peak?

options.E: Inflation is projected to be constant across all quarters.

questions.explanation: The RBI's projections for CPI inflation in 2024-25 are 4.1% in Q2, 4.8% in Q3, and 4.2% in Q4. The peak inflation is therefore projected for Q3.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What trend is anticipated in the quarterly real GDP growth rate during FY 2025-26 as per RBI's structural model estimates?

options.A: It is expected to remain constant at 7.1%.
options.B: It is projected to start at its highest point in Q1 and then moderate.
options.C: It is projected to progressively increase from Q1 to Q4.
options.D: It is expected to dip in Q2 and recover in H2.
options.E: It is projected to be volatile with no clear trend.

questions.explanation: For 2025-26, structural model estimates indicate real GDP growth with Q1 at 7.3 per cent, Q2 at 7.2 per cent, and Q3 and Q4 both at 7.0 per cent. This shows the growth rate is expected to start at its highest and then moderate through the year.
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The Reserve Bank's baseline projection for real GDP growth for 2024-25 is 7.0 per cent. (Page 18, Table I.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate that the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to keep unchanged through the second half of FY 2023-24?
questions.explanation: The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept the policy repo rate unchanged at 6.50 per cent through H2 of 2023-24. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the baseline assumption for the Indian basket of crude oil price for the projections in 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The baseline assumption for crude price (Indian basket) is retained at US$ 85 per barrel during 2024-25. (Page 13, Table I.2)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Second Advance Estimates (SAE) released by the NSO, what was the real GDP growth rate for Q3:2023-24?
questions.explanation: Real GDP growth for Q3:2023-24 was placed at 8.4 per cent, outpacing consensus forecasts by a wide margin. (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Core inflation, which is CPI excluding food and fuel, fell to what level in February 2024, marking one of the lowest prints in the current CPI series?
questions.explanation: In February 2024, core inflation (i.e., CPI excluding food and fuel) fell to 3.4 per cent, among the lowest prints in the current CPI series (2012=100). (Page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected real GDP growth for Q1 of the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Real GDP growth is expected at 7.0 per cent in 2024-25, with a specific projection of 7.1 per cent in Q1. (Page 19)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Gross Fiscal Deficit (GFD) for the central government is projected to be what percentage of GDP for 2024-25 in the interim union budget?
questions.explanation: For 2024-25, the interim union budget projects the gross fiscal deficit (GFD) at 5.1 per cent of GDP. (Page 52, and Table III.2 on page 53)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the RBI's projected headline CPI inflation for Q2 of 2024-25?
questions.explanation: CPI inflation is projected with quarterly figures of 4.9 per cent in Q1, 3.8 per cent in Q2, 4.6 per cent in Q3 and 4.5 per cent in Q4 for 2024-25. (Page 17)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Capacity utilisation (CU) in the manufacturing sector rose to what percentage in Q3:2023-24, remaining above its long-term average?
questions.explanation: Capacity utilisation (CU) in the manufacturing sector rose to 74.7 per cent in Q3:2023-24 from 74.0 per cent recorded in the previous quarter. (Page 50)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the December 2023 MPC meeting, the real GDP growth projection for 2023-24 was revised upwards to what percentage?
questions.explanation: At the time of the December 2023 meeting, the projection of real GDP growth for 2023-24 was revised up to 7.0 per cent. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under a risk scenario where global growth is 100 basis points lower than the baseline, what is the estimated impact on India's domestic growth and inflation, respectively?

options.A: 15 bps lower growth and 7 bps lower inflation
options.B: 30 bps higher growth and 15 bps higher inflation
options.C: 30 bps lower growth and 15 bps lower inflation
options.D: 50 bps lower growth and 30 bps lower inflation
options.E: 15 bps higher growth and 30 bps lower inflation

questions.explanation: In a scenario where global growth is 100 bps lower than the baseline, the report estimates that domestic growth and inflation could be around 30 bps and 15 bps, respectively, below their baseline trajectories. (Page 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the voting pattern of the MPC on the resolution to keep the policy repo rate unchanged in the October 2023, December 2023, and February 2024 meetings, respectively?
questions.explanation: The MPC unanimously decided to keep the repo rate at 6.50% in the October and December 2023 meetings. In the February 2024 meeting, the decision was made by a 5-1 majority. (Page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In response to the cumulative 250 bps repo rate hike during the tightening period from May 2022 to February 2024, what was the corresponding increase in the Weighted Average Lending Rate (WALR) on fresh rupee loans?
questions.explanation: During the tightening period from May 2022 to February 2024, the WALR on fresh rupee loans of Scheduled Commercial Banks increased by 185 basis points in response to the 250 bps repo rate hike. (Page 84, Table IV.5)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the analysis of distributional characteristics of household inflation expectations, which of the following measures were found to be significant with a negative sign, suggesting their utility in predicting one year ahead inflation?

options.E: Standard deviation, Interquartile range, and Skewness

questions.explanation: The model's estimates suggest that measures of dispersion like standard deviation and interquartile range, as well as skewness, are significant with a negative sign in predicting one year ahead inflation, whereas median and mean were found to be not significant. (Page 16, Table I.1.1)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the policy repo rate set to by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) in its February 2025 meeting?
questions.explanation: In its February 2025 meeting, the MPC unanimously voted to reduce the policy repo rate by 25 basis points from 6.50 per cent to 6.25 per cent. (page 12, 13)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline consumer price index (CPI) inflation print for February 2025, which marked a seven-month low?
questions.explanation: Headline CPI inflation eased to a seven-month low of 3.6 per cent in February 2025, driven by a sharp decline in vegetable prices inflation. (page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Monetary Policy Committee's (MPC) stance following its October 2024 meeting?
questions.explanation: In the October 2024 meeting, the MPC unanimously decided to change the stance from ‘withdrawal of accommodation’ to ‘neutral’ to provide flexibility in monitoring the economic outlook. (page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In December 2024, the Reserve Bank implemented a measure to ease liquidity conditions. What was this measure?

options.A: Reduced the policy repo rate by 50 bps
options.B: Reduced the cash reserve ratio (CRR) by 50 bps
options.C: Increased the marginal standing facility (MSF) rate
options.D: Conducted Open Market Sale of securities
options.E: Reduced the statutory liquidity ratio (SLR) by 25 bps

questions.explanation: In December 2024, the Reserve Bank reduced the cash reserve ratio (CRR) maintained by banks by 50 basis points to ease liquidity conditions. (page 12)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth rate in Q3:2024-25?
questions.explanation: Real GDP growth for Q3:2024-25 was placed at 6.2 per cent year-on-year, driven by robust private and government consumption expenditure. (page 11)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the headline CPI inflation projected for 2025-26, assuming a normal monsoon?
questions.explanation: Assuming a normal monsoon for the next year, the CPI inflation for 2025-26 is projected at 4.2 per cent. (page 13)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Second Advance Estimate (SAE) for 2024-25, what was the estimated production growth for oilseeds over the previous year?
questions.explanation: The second advance estimate (SAE) for 2024-25 indicates that oilseeds production increased by 8.4 per cent over the previous year. (Table III.12, page 61)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What percentage of headline inflation was contributed by imported components in February 2025?
questions.explanation: The contribution of imported components to headline inflation registered a sequential increase since October and was at 21 per cent in February 2025. (page 30)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a scenario where global growth turns out to be 100 bps lower than the baseline assumption, what is the estimated consequential impact on India's domestic growth and inflation, respectively?
questions.explanation: Under the Global Growth Uncertainties risk scenario, if global growth is 100 bps lower than baseline, domestic growth could be lower by around 30 bps and inflation could be lower by around 15 bps. (page 21)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the analysis of inflation expectations among different economic agents, which group demonstrates the fastest reaction to deviations in actual inflation from its long-run steady state?

options.E: All groups react at the same speed

questions.explanation: The report's VEC model analysis finds that financial sector employees have a higher adjustment factor (Error Correction, α) compared to other groups, suggesting a faster reaction to any deviation in actual inflation from the long-run steady state. (Box I.1, page 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Considering the risk scenarios for the Indian economy, what would be the estimated impact on inflation and GDP growth if the INR appreciates by 5 per cent relative to the baseline?

options.A: Inflation moderates by 25 bps, GDP growth moderates by 35 bps
options.B: Inflation rises by 35 bps, GDP growth benefits by 25 bps
options.C: Inflation moderates by 35 bps, GDP growth moderates by 25 bps
options.D: Inflation rises by 25 bps, GDP growth moderates by 35 bps
options.E: Inflation moderates by 50 bps, GDP growth is unaffected

questions.explanation: In the scenario where the INR appreciates by 5 per cent relative to the baseline, it is estimated that inflation could moderate by around 35 bps and GDP growth could moderate by around 25 bps. (page 23)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the long-run estimates of the Vector Error Correction (VEC) model presented, changes in which of the following variables were found to have a statistically significant impact on the inflation expectations of daily workers but not on those of financial sector employees?

options.C: Share of government expenditure in GDP (govt_share)

questions.explanation: The VEC model results in Table 1 show that 'ln_crude_oil' has a statistically significant coefficient (4.127***) for daily workers but an insignificant one (1.248) for financial sector employees, indicating it impacts the former's inflation expectations but not the latter's. (Box I.1, page 16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of September 2023?
questions.explanation: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) fell to a multi-year low of 3.2 per cent in September 2023. (Page 19, 64)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as recorded in September 2023?
questions.explanation: For scheduled commercial banks (SCBs), the capital to risk-weighted assets ratio (CRAR) stood at 16.8 per cent in September 2023. (Page 19, 63)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of September 2023, what was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for the Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) sector?
questions.explanation: The CRAR of NBFCs stood at 27.6 per cent in September 2023, which is well above the regulatory minimum of 15 per cent. (Page 19, 71)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Household net financial savings (HNFS) as a percentage of GDP fell significantly in 2022-23 compared to the pandemic peak. What was the HNFS to GDP ratio in 2022-23?
questions.explanation: Household net financial savings (HNFS) fell sharply to 5.1 per cent of GDP in 2022-23 from 11.5 per cent in 2020-21, driven by a rapid rise in financial liabilities. (Page 50)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the macro stress tests for credit risk, what is the projected Gross NPA (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks by September 2024 under the baseline scenario?
questions.explanation: Under the baseline scenario of the macro stress tests, the GNPA ratio of all SCBs is projected to improve to 3.1 per cent by September 2024 from the current level of 3.2 per cent. (Page 91)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Bank credit to NBFCs has grown significantly over the past two years. What was the compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of bank lending to NBFCs from June 2021 to June 2023?
questions.explanation: Bank lending to NBFCs increased at a CAGR of 26.3 per cent during the past two years (i.e., from June 2021 to June 2023), which was well above the overall bank credit growth of 14.8 per cent. (Page 67)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In November 2023, the RBI increased the risk weights on certain consumer credit exposures. By how much did the risk weight on credit card receivables for Scheduled Commercial Banks increase?
questions.explanation: The risk weights on credit card receivables of SCBs were increased by 25 percentage points to 125 per cent as part of regulatory measures towards consumer credit. (Page 127)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the projected Gross NPA (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks by September 2024 if the macroeconomic environment deteriorates into a severe stress scenario?
questions.explanation: Macro stress tests indicate that if the macroeconomic environment worsens to a severe stress scenario, the GNPA ratio for all SCBs may rise from 3.2 per cent to 4.4 per cent by September 2024. (Page 91)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Following the RBI's recent increase in risk weights on certain consumer credit segments, what is the estimated decline in the system-level Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio of the banking system (PSBs + PVBs)?
questions.explanation: Adjusting for the increase in risk weights, the CRAR of the banking system is estimated to decline by 71 bps to 16.0 per cent, and the Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio is estimated to fall by 58 bps to 13.2 per cent. (Page 68)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A contagion analysis was conducted to assess systemic risk from bank failures. In a scenario where the single bank with the maximum capacity to cause contagion fails, what would be the solvency loss as a percentage of the total Tier 1 capital of SCBs as of September 2023?
questions.explanation: The contagion analysis for September 2023 indicates that if the bank with the maximum capacity to cause contagion losses fails, it would result in a solvency loss of 3.63 per cent of the total Tier 1 capital of SCBs. (Page 119, Table 2.16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of September 2024, reaching a multi-year low?
questions.explanation: The gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio of scheduled commercial banks fell to a multi-year low of 2.6 per cent in September 2024, buoyed by falling slippages and higher write-offs. (Page 55)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was India's real Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth projected at for the financial year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: Real gross domestic product (GDP) for India is projected to grow at 6.6 per cent in 2024-25, supported by a revival in rural consumption and strong services exports. (Page 24)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Provisioning Coverage Ratio (PCR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of September 2024?
questions.explanation: The provisioning coverage ratio (PCR) of SCBs improved further to 77.0 per cent in September 2024, largely due to proactive provisioning by Public Sector Banks. (Page 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Systemic Risk Survey (SRS) conducted in November 2024, what percentage of respondents assessed 'better or similar' prospects for the Indian banking sector over a one-year horizon?
questions.explanation: The November 2024 Systemic Risk Survey found that 60 per cent of the respondents assessed better or similar prospects for the Indian banking sector over a one-year horizon. (Pages 22, 76, 151)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the central government's gross fiscal deficit (GFD) projected to be as a percentage of GDP for the budget estimates (BE) of 2024-25?
questions.explanation: As per the provisional accounts (PA) for 2023-24, the GFD was 5.6 per cent. It is projected to go down further to 4.9 per cent in 2024-25 (BE). (Page 39, Table 1.4)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: India's weightage in the MSCI Emerging Markets Index (MSCI-EMI) has seen a significant increase, reflecting the market's outperformance. What was this weightage in November 2024?
questions.explanation: The Indian equity market has outperformed emerging market peers, leading to an increase in India’s weightage in the MSCI-EMI from 9.2 per cent in March 2019 to 19.9 per cent in November 2024. (Page 46)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The microfinance sector exhibited signs of stress during H1:2024-25. The share of stressed assets, defined as loans 31-180 days past due (dpd), rose to what level in September 2024?
