questions.explanation: During H1:2024-25, the share of stressed assets in the microfinance sector increased, with 31-180 days past due (dpd) rising from 2.15 per cent in March 2024 to 4.30 per cent in September 2024. (Page 67)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the macro stress tests conducted for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs), how many banks were projected to potentially breach the minimum capital requirement of 9 per cent CRAR by March 2026 under the hypothetical 'adverse scenario 1'?
questions.explanation: The stress test results reveal that under 'adverse scenario 1', the aggregate CRAR of SCBs may deplete to 14.3 per cent, and four banks may breach the minimum capital requirement of 9 per cent by March 2026. (Page 90)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the sectoral credit risk analysis, a two standard deviation shock to the GNPA ratio of which one of the following industrial sub-sectors is projected to cause the largest reduction in the system-level CRAR of SCBs?
questions.explanation: Table 2.1 shows that a two standard deviation shock to the 'Basic Metal and Metal Products' sub-sector would reduce the system-level CRAR by 17 basis points, the highest among all listed sectors. (Page 95)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In a contagion analysis that incorporates the impact of macroeconomic shocks, how many banks were projected to see their Tier I capital ratio fall below the 7 per cent regulatory minimum under 'adverse scenario 1'?
questions.explanation: In a scenario combining macroeconomic shocks with contagion effects, it was found that the Tier I capital ratio would fall below 7 per cent for four banks in adverse scenario 1, resulting in marginal additional solvency losses to the system. (Page 125)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Gross Non-Performing Assets (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) reached a multi-year low at the end of March 2024. What was this ratio?
questions.explanation: According to the report, the gross non-performing assets (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks fell to a multi-year low of 2.8 per cent as of March 2024. (Page 18, 58)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The report states that the capital to risk-weighted assets ratio (CRAR) for SCBs stood at 16.8 per cent in March 2024, which is well above the regulatory minimum. (Page 18, 22)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Return on Equity (RoE) for Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) remained strong, reaching a near decadal high in March 2024. What was this reported figure?
questions.explanation: In March 2024, the Return on Equity (RoE) for the banking sector was 13.8 per cent, bolstered by high net interest margins and strong credit demand. (Page 18, 58)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the May 2024 Systemic Risk Survey (SRS), which of the following was identified by respondents as the most significant near-term risk to domestic financial stability?

options.E: Commodity Price and Crude Oil shocks

questions.explanation: The report's Systemic Risk Survey carried out in May 2024 identified geopolitical risks, tightening of global financial conditions, and capital outflows as major near-term risks. The chart on potential risks shows Geopolitical Risk as the highest-rated concern. (Page 19, 72)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the debt share of non-financial corporates with an Interest Coverage Ratio (ICR) of less than or equal to one in 2023-24, indicating their financial vulnerability?
questions.explanation: Table 1.2 in the report shows that the debt share of firms with an Interest Coverage Ratio (ICR) of less than or equal to one, a key indicator of financial vulnerability, declined to 18.0 per cent in 2023-24 from 21.0 per cent in the previous year. (Page 40)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The share of unsecured loans extended by the Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) sector moderated between March 2023 and March 2024. What was the share as of March 2024?
questions.explanation: The report states that the share of unsecured loans extended by the NBFC sector fell from 32.2 per cent of total loans to 22.9 per cent between March 2023 and March 2024. (Page 65)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Among the different categories of Regulated Entities (REs) that reported cyber incidents, which category had the highest share of incidents (41 per cent) falling into higher risk categories?
questions.explanation: Analysis of cyber incidents shows that Urban Co-operative Banks (UCBs) had the highest share of incidents, at 41 per cent, in higher risk categories amongst all Regulated Entities. (Page 70)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the macro stress tests for credit risk, what is the projected aggregate Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for 46 major banks by March 2025 under the severe stress scenario?
questions.explanation: The stress test results reveal that under a severe stress scenario, the aggregate CRAR of 46 major banks may go down from 16.7 per cent in March 2024 to 13.0 per cent by March 2025, which would still be above the minimum regulatory requirement of 9 per cent. (Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the contagion analysis conducted in March 2024, what would be the estimated impact if the Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) with the maximum capacity to cause solvency losses were to fail?

options.A: A 2.29% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and the failure of one bank.
options.B: A 2.29% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and no subsequent bank failures.
options.C: A 3.87% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and no subsequent bank failures.
options.D: A 3.87% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and the failure of one bank.
options.E: A 5.06% loss in the banking system's Tier 1 capital and no subsequent bank failures.

questions.explanation: The solvency contagion analysis showed that the hypothetical failure of the top NBFC would result in a 2.29 per cent loss of the banking system's total Tier 1 capital, but it would not lead to the failure of any bank. The 3.87% figure corresponds to an HFC failure. (Page 116)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: In the credit risk sensitivity analysis under a severe shock scenario (2 Standard Deviation shock on GNPA ratio), what is the number of banks projected to fail to meet the minimum regulatory CRAR and their corresponding share of total SCB assets?
questions.explanation: The bank-level stress tests under a severe shock scenario indicate that six banks, which collectively hold 11.2 per cent of the total assets of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs), may fail to maintain the regulatory minimum level of CRAR. (Page 87)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Gross Non-Performing Asset (GNPA) ratio for Scheduled Commercial Banks as of March 2025?
questions.explanation: According to the performance metrics of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs), the Gross NPA ratio reached a multi-decadal low of 2.3 per cent as of March 2025. (Source: Page 55, Chart 1.44)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Domestic headline consumer price index (CPI) inflation recorded a six-year low in May 2025. What was this inflation rate?
questions.explanation: The report states that domestic inflation has been steadily declining, with the headline consumer price index (CPI) inflation recording a six-year low of 2.8 per cent in May 2025. (Source: Page 27, Para 1.16)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What was the Capital to Risk-weighted Assets Ratio (CRAR) for Scheduled Commercial Banks as of March 2025?
questions.explanation: The CRAR of Scheduled Commercial Banks (SCBs) stood at a record high of 17.3 per cent as of March 2025, indicating strong capital buffers in the banking system. (Source: Page 55, Chart 1.44 and Page 80, Chart 2.5a)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: According to the Systemic Risk Survey (SRS) conducted in May 2025, which of the following groups of factors were identified as the major near-term risks to domestic financial stability?

options.B: Real estate price correction and high interest rates
options.C: Slowdown in domestic consumption and investment
options.D: Geopolitical conflicts, capital outflows, and reciprocal tariff/trade slowdowns
options.E: Climate risks and operational risks in the financial sector

questions.explanation: The Assessment of Systemic Risk section, based on the May 2025 survey, identifies geopolitical conflicts, capital outflows, and reciprocal tariff/trade slowdowns as the major near-term risks to domestic financial stability. (Source: Page 20, 'Assessment of Systemic Risk' section)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As of March 2025, the ownership share of Domestic Institutional Investors (DIIs) in NSE-listed companies surpassed that of Foreign Portfolio Investors (FPIs). What were their respective ownership shares?
questions.explanation: As of March 2025, FPI ownership in NSE-listed companies touched a decadal low at 17.5%, while DIIs' share surpassed it, reaching 18.1%. (Source: Page 41, Chart 1.27d)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The share of floating rate loans in the total gross advances of select scheduled commercial banks increased to what percentage in March 2025?
questions.explanation: The share of floating rate loans in total gross advances for the select banks increased from 72.0 per cent in March 2023 to 75.7 per cent in March 2025. (Source: Page 59, Para 1.59 and Table 1.3)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the macro stress test's Adverse Scenario 1 (Geopolitical risk scenario), what is the projected aggregate CRAR for 46 major Scheduled Commercial Banks by March 2027?
questions.explanation: The macro stress tests results revealed that the aggregate CRAR of 46 major SCBs may decline to 14.2 per cent by March 2027 under the adverse scenario 1 (Geopolitical risk scenario) from 17.2 per cent in March 2025. (Source: Page 83, Para 2.13 and Page 84, Chart 2.9a)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Based on the credit risk sensitivity analysis, under a severe shock scenario of a two standard deviation increase in the GNPA ratio, how many banks are projected to breach the minimum CRAR, and what is their corresponding share in total SCB assets?

options.D: No banks would breach the minimum CRAR

questions.explanation: Bank-level stress tests indicated that under the severe shock scenario (two SD), three banks with a share of 6.1 per cent in SCBs’ total assets may breach the regulatory minimum level of CRAR. (Source: Page 85, Para 2.17 and Chart 2.12b)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The reverse stress test for system-wide credit concentration risk evaluates the number of top borrower defaults required to deplete the system-level CRAR by specific margins. For March 2025, the default of how many of the top 100 largest individual borrowers would result in a 200 basis point depletion in system CRAR?
questions.explanation: The reverse stress test using the cumulative CRAR depletion curve for March 2025 revealed that it would take the top 7, 22, and 46 borrowers to default to deplete the system level CRAR by 100, 200, and 300 basis points, respectively. (Source: Page 88, Box 2.1, Chart 2b)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: An analysis of sectoral asset quality for SCBs as of March 2025 shows that one sector continued to record the highest GNPA ratio. Which sector was this, and what was its share in the total GNPA of all SCBs?

options.A: Industry, with a 22.3% share of total GNPA
options.B: Services, with a 25.9% share of total GNPA
options.C: Personal Loans, with a 16.9% share of total GNPA
options.D: Agriculture, with a 34.6% share of total GNPA
options.E: Infrastructure, with a 29.0% share of total GNPA

questions.explanation: As per Chart 2.3a, the Agriculture sector continued to record the highest GNPA ratio among all major sectors. The note accompanying the chart indicates that the numbers in parentheses on the x-axis represent the share of that sector's GNPA in the total GNPA of SCBs as of March 2025. For Agriculture, this share was 34.6%. (Source: Page 77, Chart 2.3a and Para 2.6)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the assessment year beginning on or after April 1, 2025, what is the income tax rate applicable for an individual under the new tax regime for the total income slab of Rs. 3,00,001 to Rs. 7,00,000?
questions.explanation: As per the amendment to Section 115BAC, for the assessment year beginning on or after April 1, 2025, the income tax rate for the total income slab from Rs. 3,00,001 to Rs. 7,00,000 is 5 per cent. This is a change from the previous slab of Rs. 3,00,001 to Rs. 6,00,000. (Page 52)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024, introduced a new scheme for the resolution of direct tax disputes. What is this scheme named?

options.B: The Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024
options.D: The Direct Tax Dispute Resolution Scheme, 2024
options.E: The Direct Tax Kar Samadhan Scheme, 2024

questions.explanation: Chapter IV of the Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024, is titled 'THE DIRECT TAX VIVAD SE VISHWAS SCHEME, 2024'. Section 88(1) states, 'This Scheme may be called the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024.' (Page 80)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amended Section 16 of the Income-tax Act, what is the revised standard deduction for salaried individuals who opt for the new tax regime, effective from April 1, 2025?
questions.explanation: A new proviso inserted in Section 16(ia) states that where income-tax is computed under Section 115BAC, the words 'fifty thousand rupees' shall be substituted with 'seventy-five thousand rupees'. This amendment is effective from April 1, 2025. (Page 39, 168)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the rate of 'Health and Education Cess on income-tax' as specified in the financial proposals for 2024-2025?
questions.explanation: Section 2, sub-section (11) specifies that the income-tax and applicable surcharge shall be further increased by an additional surcharge called the 'Health and Education Cess on income-tax', calculated at the rate of four per cent. (Page 32)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The rate of tax deduction at source (TDS) on commission on the sale of lottery tickets under section 194G has been revised. What is the new TDS rate?
questions.explanation: As per the amendment to section 194G, the words 'five per cent.' have been substituted with 'two per cent.' for TDS on commission on the sale of lottery tickets, effective from October 1, 2024. (Page 72, 199)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For a domestic company whose total turnover in the previous year 2022-23 did not exceed four hundred crore rupees, what is the applicable rate of income-tax for the assessment year 2024-25?
questions.explanation: The First Schedule, Part III, Paragraph E specifies the rates for companies. For a domestic company with a total turnover not exceeding four hundred crore rupees in PY 2022-23, the income-tax rate is 25 per cent of the total income. (Page 142)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new section 44BBC has been inserted for computing profits for non-residents engaged in the business of operating cruise ships. What percentage of the aggregate amounts received is deemed to be profits and gains of such business?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted section 44BBC(1) states that for a non-resident assessee in the business of operating cruise ships, a sum equal to twenty per cent of the aggregate amounts specified in sub-section (2) shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of such business. (Page 41, 170)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The TDS rate for e-commerce operators under section 194-O has been revised. What is the new rate of tax deduction on the gross amount of sales or services?
questions.explanation: The amendment to section 194-O substitutes the words 'one per cent.' with '0.1 per cent.' for the TDS rate applicable to e-commerce operators, effective from October 1, 2024. (Page 73, 201)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge rate on income tax for a co-operative society with a total income exceeding one crore rupees but not exceeding ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: For every co-operative society, the surcharge on income tax is calculated at the rate of seven per cent if the total income exceeds one crore rupees but does not exceed ten crore rupees. (Page 13, 120)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new Section 194T has been proposed for TDS on payments to partners of firms. What is the rate of TDS on payments like salary, bonus, or interest to a partner?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted Section 194T(1) mandates that a firm responsible for paying any sum like salary, remuneration, commission, bonus, or interest to a partner shall deduct income-tax thereon at the rate of ten per cent. (Page 73, 201)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge applicable on income tax for a domestic company if its total income exceeds ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: In the case of a domestic company having a total income exceeding ten crore rupees, the surcharge on income tax is calculated at the rate of twelve per cent of such income-tax. (Page 14, 122)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new penalty Section 271GC has been inserted for failure to furnish a statement under section 285. What is the penalty if the failure continues for more than three months?
questions.explanation: Section 271GC specifies a penalty for failure to furnish a statement. It is one thousand rupees per day if the failure does not exceed three months, and one lakh rupees in any other case (i.e., if failure exceeds three months). (Page 79, 209)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the purposes of the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, what is the 'specified date' on which appeals, petitions, or applications must be pending?
questions.explanation: Under the definitions for the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024, Section 89(1)(n) defines 'specified date' as the 22nd day of July, 2024. (Page 83)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The holding period for classifying a capital asset as a 'short-term capital asset' has been amended. What is the new maximum holding period immediately preceding the date of transfer for an asset to be considered short-term?
questions.explanation: Clause 3 of the Bill amends section 2(42A) of the Income-tax Act. It proposes to amend the clause to provide that a 'short-term capital asset' would mean a capital asset held by an assessee for not more than twenty-four months, reducing it from the previous thirty-six months. (Page 33, 162)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The TDS rate under Section 194DA for payments in respect of life insurance policies has been reduced. What is the new rate effective from October 1, 2024?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 194DA of the Income-tax Act substitutes the words 'five per cent.' with 'two per cent.', thus reducing the TDS rate on such payments. This change is effective from October 1, 2024. (Page 72, 199)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: As per the amendments to the Income-tax Act, what is the maximum deduction allowed to an employer for contributions to an employee's pension scheme under Section 80CCD, as a percentage of the employee's salary?
questions.explanation: Clause 12 of the Bill amends section 36(1)(iva) to increase the amount of employer contribution allowed as a deduction from ten per cent to fourteen per cent of the salary of the employee in the previous year. This aligns the deduction for all employers with that for the Central Government. (Page 39-40, 168)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The time limit for issuing a notice for income escaping assessment under Section 148 has been revised. A notice can be issued if up to five years and three months have elapsed, provided the escaped income is likely to amount to or exceed a certain threshold. What is this threshold?
questions.explanation: The substituted Section 149(1)(b) allows for a notice to be issued if three years and three months, but not more than five years and three months, have elapsed from the end of the relevant assessment year, provided the Assessing Officer has evidence that the income chargeable to tax which has escaped assessment amounts to or is likely to amount to fifty lakh rupees or more. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The Finance (No. 2) Bill, 2024 has amended the TDS rate for rent payments by individuals/HUFs under Section 194-IB. What is the new reduced TDS rate?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 194-IB(1) substitutes the words 'five per cent.' with 'two per cent.', thereby reducing the TDS rate on rent payments exceeding fifty thousand rupees per month by individuals or HUFs. The change takes effect from October 1, 2024. (Page 72-73, 200)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For a transfer taking place on or after July 23, 2024, what is the revised tax rate on long-term capital gains exceeding Rs. 1,25,000 under Section 112A of the Income-tax Act?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 112A(2)(i) specifies that for any transfer taking place on or after the 23rd day of July, 2024, the tax rate on long-term capital gains exceeding one lakh twenty-five thousand rupees will be twelve and one-half per cent (12.5%). (Page 49, 173)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: An individual opts for the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024. Their tax arrear relates to disputed interest where they were an appellant on or before January 31, 2020. If they pay the amount on January 15, 2025, what percentage of the disputed interest is payable?
questions.explanation: According to the table in Section 90, for tax arrears related to disputed interest where the declarant was an appellant on or before 31st Jan 2020, the amount payable is 30% if paid by 31st Dec 2024. If paid on or after 1st Jan 2025, the amount payable is thirty-five per cent of the disputed interest. (Page 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The tax rate on short-term capital gains under Section 111A has been revised based on the date of transfer. For a transfer occurring on August 10, 2024, what is the applicable tax rate?
questions.explanation: Section 29 amends Section 111A to introduce a dual-rate structure. For any transfer which takes place on or after the 23rd day of July, 2024, the tax rate on short-term capital gains under this section is twenty per cent. The rate remains fifteen per cent for transfers before this date. (Page 47, 169)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: An individual opting for the new tax regime (Section 115BAC) has a total income of Rs. 2.5 crore, which includes Rs. 50 lakh of dividend income. What is the maximum surcharge rate applicable on the income tax computed on the dividend income portion?
questions.explanation: A proviso to Section 2 states that where the provisions of sub-section (1A) of section 115BAC are applicable and the total income includes any income by way of dividend, the rate of surcharge on the income-tax in respect of that part of income shall not exceed fifteen per cent, irrespective of the total income level. (Page 17)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Which of the following scenarios would make a person ineligible for the Direct Tax Vivad Se Vishwas Scheme, 2024?

options.A: An appeal is pending before the Commissioner (Appeals) as on the specified date.
options.B: The tax arrear relates to an assessment year for which prosecution has been instituted on or before the date of filing the declaration.
options.C: An application for revision under section 264 is pending as on the specified date.
options.D: The disputed tax amount is less than Rs. 10 lakh.
options.E: The tax arrear relates to disputed interest only.

questions.explanation: Section 96(a)(ii) explicitly states that the provisions of the Scheme shall not apply in respect of a tax arrear relating to an assessment year for which prosecution has been instituted on or before the date of filing of declaration. The other options describe eligible scenarios. (Page 88)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amended Section 2(42A), the holding period for an asset to be a short-term capital asset is now twenty-four months. This amendment takes effect retrospectively. What is the effective date of this change?
questions.explanation: The notes on Clause 3, which amends Section 2(42A), explicitly state at the end, 'This amendment will take effect retrospectively from 23rd July, 2024.' This makes the new 24-month rule applicable from this specific date. (Page 162)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A non-resident individual, whose income is chargeable under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC), has an aggregate income of Rs. 6 crore subject to TDS. What is the maximum rate of surcharge that will be applied to the TDS calculation?
questions.explanation: As per Section 2, sub-section (6)(a) read with the proviso, where the income of a person is chargeable to tax under sub-section (1A) of section 115BAC, the rate of surcharge on the tax deducted shall not exceed twenty-five per cent. This caps the surcharge even though the income exceeds five crore rupees, which would normally attract a 37% surcharge. (Page 19)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the rate of the additional surcharge known as 'Health and Education Cess on income-tax' as specified in the Finance Bill, 2025?
questions.explanation: The Finance Bill, 2025 specifies that the income-tax shall be further increased by an additional surcharge called the 'Health and Education Cess on income-tax', calculated at the rate of four per cent of such income-tax and surcharge. (Page 31)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For any previous year relevant to the assessment year beginning on or after April 1, 2026, what is the nil rate of tax applicable for total income under the amended Section 115BAC?
questions.explanation: As per the amendment to Section 115BAC, for the assessment year beginning on or after April 1, 2026, the income tax rate is 'Nil' for individuals with a total income of up to Rs. 4,00,000. (Page 46)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amendment to section 80CCD, what is the maximum annual deduction allowed to a parent or guardian for contributions made to a minor's account under the National Pension Scheme Vatsalya Accounts?
questions.explanation: A new proviso in section 80CCD(1B) allows a deduction for payment or deposit made to a minor's account under the pension scheme, subject to the condition that the aggregate amount of deduction shall not exceed fifty thousand rupees. (Page 42, 148)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the assessment year 2025-26, what is the applicable surcharge rate on income tax for an individual with a total income exceeding fifty lakh rupees but not exceeding one crore rupees?
questions.explanation: For an individual with a total income exceeding fifty lakh rupees but not exceeding one crore rupees, the surcharge on income-tax is calculated at the rate of ten per cent. (Page 12, 83)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For individuals who are residents in India and aged eighty years or more, what is the basic exemption limit where no income tax is charged for the assessment year 2025-26?
questions.explanation: According to The First Schedule, Part I, for every individual resident in India aged eighty years or more, no income tax is levied where the total income does not exceed Rs. 5,00,000. (Page 82)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the income tax rate for total income from Rs. 4,00,001 to Rs. 8,00,000 for individuals under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC) for the assessment year 2026-27?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 115BAC specifies a tax rate of 5 per cent for total income ranging from Rs. 4,00,001 to Rs. 8,00,000, effective from the assessment year 2026-27. (Page 46)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For the assessment year 2025-26, what is the surcharge rate on income tax for a firm or local authority whose total income exceeds one crore rupees?
questions.explanation: In the case of every firm or local authority with a total income exceeding one crore rupees, the income tax shall be increased by a surcharge calculated at the rate of twelve per cent. (Page 13, 85, 86)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The threshold for no deduction of tax at source on rent under Section 194-I has been revised. What is the new monthly rent threshold below which no TDS is required?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 194-I substitutes the first proviso to state that no deduction shall be made where the income by way of rent credited or paid for a month or part of a month does not exceed fifty thousand rupees. (Page 56)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The benefit for eligible start-ups under Section 80-IAC, which provides for a 100% deduction of profits for three consecutive years, has been extended. The benefit is now available to start-ups incorporated before which date?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 80-IAC extends the benefit period for eligible start-ups for another five years, making the benefit available to start-ups incorporated before the 1st April, 2030. (Page 43, 148)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Effective from April 1, 2026, the tax rebate under Section 87A for individuals under the new tax regime (Section 115BAC) has been increased. What are the new income and rebate limits, respectively?

options.A: Income up to Rs. 7 lakh, rebate up to Rs. 25,000
options.B: Income up to Rs. 10 lakh, rebate up to Rs. 50,000
options.C: Income up to Rs. 12 lakh, rebate up to Rs. 60,000
options.D: Income up to Rs. 15 lakh, rebate up to Rs. 75,000
options.E: Income up to Rs. 9 lakh, rebate up to Rs. 45,000

questions.explanation: The amendment to the proviso of Section 87A substitutes 'seven hundred thousand rupees' with 'twelve hundred thousand rupees' and 'twenty-five thousand rupees' with 'sixty thousand rupees', raising the income limit to Rs. 12 lakh and the rebate limit to Rs. 60,000. (Page 43, 149)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge rate applicable to a domestic company for the assessment year 2025-26 if its total income exceeds one crore rupees but does not exceed ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: For a domestic company with a total income exceeding one crore rupees but not exceeding ten crore rupees, the surcharge on income-tax is calculated at the rate of seven per cent. (Page 87, 106)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the surcharge rate applicable to a co-operative society for the assessment year 2025-26 if its total income exceeds ten crore rupees?
questions.explanation: In the case of every co-operative society having a total income exceeding ten crore rupees, the surcharge on income-tax is calculated at the rate of twelve per cent. (Page 13, 85)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The threshold for TDS on payment of compensation on acquisition of immovable property under Section 194LA has been revised. What is the new aggregate payment limit during a financial year below which no tax is deductible?
questions.explanation: The first proviso of Section 194LA has been amended, replacing 'two lakh and fifty thousand rupees' with 'five lakh rupees' as the threshold for TDS on compensation payments. (Page 57, 168)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amendment to Section 194LBC, what is the new uniform rate of tax to be deducted at source on income payable to a resident investor from a securitisation trust?
questions.explanation: Section 194LBC has been amended to provide a reduced uniform TDS rate of 10% on income in respect of investment in a securitisation trust, replacing the previous differential rates of 25% and 30%. (Page 57, 168)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The time limit for filing an updated income tax return under Section 139(8A) has been extended. What is the new maximum period for filing an updated return from the end of the relevant assessment year?
questions.explanation: The amendment to sub-section (8A) of Section 139 extends the time-limit to file an updated return from twenty-four months to forty-eight months from the end of the relevant assessment year. (Page 50, 157)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The commencement of operations for a unit in an International Financial Services Centre leasing an aircraft or ship has been extended to claim deductions under Section 80LA. What is the new deadline?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 80LA extends the date of commencement of operations for a unit leasing an aircraft or a ship from 31st March, 2025 to 31st March, 2030. (Page 43, 149)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new clause (12BA) in Section 10 allows tax exemption on partial withdrawal from a minor's National Pension System account. What is the maximum percentage of contributions made by the parent/guardian that can be withdrawn tax-free?
questions.explanation: The newly inserted clause (12BA) in Section 10 provides that any payment from the NPS Trust on partial withdrawal from a minor's account is exempt to the extent it does not exceed twenty-five per cent of the contributions made. (Page 36, 141)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: What is the revised TDS threshold for income by way of insurance commission under Section 194D, below which no tax deduction is required during a financial year?
questions.explanation: The second proviso to Section 194D is amended to increase the threshold of aggregated amounts of income from insurance commission, for the requirement to deduct tax at source, from fifteen thousand rupees to twenty thousand rupees. (Page 56, 165)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amendment to Section 140B, what is the additional income-tax payable if an updated return is filed after the expiry of twenty-four months but before thirty-six months from the end of the relevant assessment year?
questions.explanation: A new clause (iii) is inserted in Section 140B(3) which prescribes that sixty per cent of the aggregate of tax and interest payable shall be the additional income-tax if the updated return is furnished after twenty-four months but before thirty-six months from the end of the relevant assessment year. (Page 50, 158)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For a scheme of amalgamation of a banking company brought into force on or after April 1, 2025, for how many assessment years can the accumulated loss of the original predecessor entity be carried forward in the hands of the successor entity?
questions.explanation: The amendment to Section 72AA specifies that for amalgamations effective on or after April 1, 2025, any loss of the predecessor entity shall be carried forward in the hands of the successor entity for not more than eight assessment years immediately succeeding the assessment year for which the loss was first computed for the original predecessor entity. (Page 41, 147)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: A new Section 44BBD introduces a special provision for computing profits for non-residents providing services or technology for setting up electronics manufacturing in India. What percentage of the aggregate amounts received or paid is deemed to be profits and gains of such business?
questions.explanation: The new Section 44BBD(1) states that a sum equal to twenty-five per cent of the aggregate of specified amounts shall be deemed to be the profits and gains of the business of the non-resident assessee, chargeable to tax under 'Profits and gains of business or profession'. (Page 39, 145)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: For which period has a retrospective exemption from service tax been granted for reinsurance services provided by insurance companies under the Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme and Modified National Agricultural Insurance Scheme?
questions.explanation: Clause 130 provides a special retrospective exemption from service tax for reinsurance services under specified schemes for the period commencing from the 1st day of April, 2011 and ending with the 30th day of June, 2017 (both days inclusive). (Page 77, 182)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: Under the amendment to Section 9A, if an eligible investment fund's aggregate participation from Indian residents exceeds 5% on April 1st or October 1st, what is the timeframe within which this must be rectified for the condition to be deemed satisfied?
questions.explanation: A new proviso in Section 9A(3)(c) states that if the aggregate participation exceeds five per cent on the first day of April or October, the condition is deemed satisfied if it is rectified within four months of that date. (Page 34, 140)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: The new Section 285BAA introduces an obligation to furnish information on crypto-asset transactions. If a reporting entity furnishes a defective statement and fails to rectify it within the prescribed time, what is the legal consequence?

options.A: A flat penalty of Rs. 1,00,000 will be imposed.
options.B: The provisions of the Act will apply as if the person had furnished inaccurate information.
options.C: The entity's registration will be cancelled immediately.
options.D: A penalty of 1% of the transaction value will be levied.
options.E: The entity will be barred from reporting for one year.

questions.explanation: According to the newly inserted Section 285BAA(2), if a defect in a furnished statement is not rectified within the given period, the provisions of the Income-tax Act shall apply as if such person had furnished inaccurate information in the statement. (Page 62, 168)
questions.subject: General_Awareness

questions.question: With effect from April 1, 2026, what will be the revised rate of tax on long-term capital gains for Foreign Institutional Investors arising from the transfer of securities (not covered under Section 112A), as per the amendment to Section 115AD?
questions.explanation: Clause 23 of the Bill amends Section 115AD, substituting the tax rate of 'ten per cent' with 'twelve and one-half per cent' for long-term capital gains on securities for FIIs, effective from 1st April, 2026. (Page 46, 152)
questions.subject: General_Awareness
